49941|event_rmks|At Learning TREK the interconnectedness between human interactions and the environment is emphasized.  By placing the students in the outdoor learning environment they gain a greater appreciation for what is around them.  As they learn about nature they also develop various leadership skills.  The adventure will last for five days. From rock climbing to caving and fishing to swimming, we will   experience everything the Big Horns have to offer.  REMARKS: This is a week long Residential Science Camp.  This program is offered in partnership with Learning TREK Inc.  Self supporting Program  ? Age restriction 14  18  ? No Scholarships, but there is a possibility of a sponsorship so please keep a list of people that inquire about this.     ? Registration deadline is June 1st  ? Located in near Red Lodge Montana  ? Minimum of 12, no more than 15||10/28/2007||
49952|event_rmks|This course is intended to provide educators with instructional tools to change practice and promote student achievement through ongoing professional development. Participants will complete the (AFT) ER&D Managing Anti-Social Behavior Program. This course will offer a non-threatening, non-judgmental learning environment, providing opportunities for thoughtful discussion about teaching and learning with colleagues and researchers.  The course blends theory and practice into meaningful strategies that promote social skills development and academic progress.    The anti-social actions of a small but powerful percentage of students in school not only put their own academic success at risk, but also threaten the learning environment for the rest of the class. This course will present research on students who have emotional and behavioral problems and who are easily provoked. Participants will learn strategies to reduce and/or prevent the occurrence of disruptive outbreaks.   This course is self-supporting. Please contact the instructors the week before the class to notify them of the enrollment status to determine if class will go   An Instructors Agreement and ETF needed to be completed for 2 team-teachers  the instructors will be paid on a per-student basis and will share a $50 per student stipend for the 2 credit class   Both instructors need to be setup with the HR office for payroll   CPSLL will conduct on site registration for extension credit on the first day of the course  Tuesday, May 31, 2005   Need to take copies of syllabus to registration.   The course will occur at the Billings Education Assoc. office at 510 North 29th Street   Fees for this class will be $125 for 1 cred||10/28/2007||

These procuesses are taught troughtout the school day in all the content areas.  Teachesr will learn to use the major components of balanced literacy in their classrooms.  Modeled reading, shared reading, independent reading, guided reading, modeled writing, interactive writing, and independent writing will be addressed.||10/28/2007||

49287|event_desc|This course will cover descriptive techniques, probability distributions, statistical inference, regression, and nonparametric methods. This is an introduction to statistics for students who may lack a background in calculus.  This course will provide a survey of the discipline with an emphasis on the application of statistical techniques to every day problems.  Upon completion of the course, students should be able to critically evaluate data, use graphical and numerical summaries, apply standard statistical inference procedures, and to draw conclusions from such analysis.||10/28/2007||
49288|event_desc|This course introduces IEP Team members to a student centered decision-making process used to identify individual student need for assistive technology. Many IEP teams are unsure how to address the issue of assistive technology in an IEP. By implementing this process, teams find they reach consensus, save money and struggling students find more success in the general education classes. Using case studies from their own situation, participants will: 1) Learn the difference between assistive technology and instructional technology; 2) Be introduced to the student centered decision-making process; 3) Define assistive technology and IEP requirements; 4) Identify local and national recources; 5) Match individual student need to appropriate technology; 6) Identify different types of non-tech, low tech and high tech as possible solutions for a target student.||10/28/2007||

49290|event_desc|This course is designed for teams of instructional personnel who are currently using technology products from IntelliTools.  It is recommended that General Educators and Special Educators attend as a team.  It is strongly recommended that OT/PT/SLP and Paraprofessionals attend with a General Education teacher.  The course will give teams with all levels of experience, from novice to advanced, time to learn new features or the programs under the guidance of a knowledgeable instructor.  Participants will be required to modify general education curriculum content to meet the needs of students with disabilities, from students with learning disabilities to those with more severe cognitive and physical impairments.  Participants will be required to share activities they have created and discuss ideas for implementing these products in a wide variety of curriculum areas.||10/28/2007||

49320|event_desc|This is a three-day workshop for beginners and experienced mosaic artist and teachers.  Participants in this workshop will have the opportunity to complete a gazing ball mosaic while learning surface preparation, breaking or cutting tesserae, adhesive function, grouting, and finishing.  This process and project will serve to practice PAS  Project Assessment Scale, an assessment tool developed by the instructor.  This experience would be valuable to any teacher who utilizes project-based learning and needs an effective procedure for evaluation.  A $20 materials fee is payable to the instructor at the start of the workshop.  In addition, you will need to purchase the book, The Mosaic Idea Book by Rosalind Wates which is available at the MSU-Billings Downtown Bookstore, 207 North Broadway.||10/28/2007||
49321|event_desc|In this class we will find and share examples of folklore in our daily lives.  (Of course, we'll explore the time-honored tales and ballads, as well). Participants in this class will learn how to (1) recognize and (2) categorize various kinds of folklore with an eye toward (3) incorporating folklore in the classroom.  We will also (4) develop the critical analysis skills necessary to distinguish folklore from fakelore.  And we will (5) analyze folklore and folk items for their meaning in our culture.  Folklore and the analysis of folklore can be used to enhance critical thinking, multicultural understanding, storytelling skills and appreciation, and literary appreciation and creativity.||10/28/2007||
49322|event_desc|In this class we will find and share examples of folklore in our daily lives.  (Of course, we'll explore the time-honored tales and ballads, as well). Participants in this class will learn how to (1) recognize and (2) categorize various kinds of folklore with an eye toward (3) incorporating folklore in the classroom.  We will also (4) develop the critical analysis skills necessary to distinguish folklore from fakelore.  And we will (5) analyze folklore and folk items for their meaning in our culture. 49323|event_desc|This course is intended for practicing teachers and focuses on the student's own classroom as the context of all of the course readings, assignments, projects, and other learning activities.  It is not a narrow exercise in experimental design but a broad survey of human inquiry.  This course is intended to introduce students to professional, disciplined ways of asking and answering questions of personal and professional importance.  I except that students taking this course do not presently posses mastery of the knowledge and skills covered in this course, which is why they take it. By encountering that with which we are unfamiliar and lack mastery, we learn.  The cognitive dissonance resulting from such encounters produces learning and growth.  Expect mastery of research design and interpretation as a result of the course, not as a prerequisite.||10/28/2007||
49324|event_desc|This course is intended for practicing teachers and focuses on the student's own classroom as the context for course readings, assignments, and other learning activities.  Focusing on advanced topics and issues in educational psychology (i.e. classroom instructional strategies consistent with human learning, dicipline-specific instruction, etc.), the course presumes undergraduate coursework in the education and educational psychology.  The course is intended to significantly contribute to each student's understanding of current psychological knowledge of human development and learning as it affects education and related human services.  Hopefully, each student will be sufficiently challenged by new "facts," ideas, relationships between facts, and ways of explaining facts to experience the cognitive dissonance required for learning to occur.||10/28/2007||

49336|event_desc|The purpose of this conference is to foster respectiful dialogue about the relationships that give life mush of its meaning and provide some of the glue that holds society together.  This conference is set up in a dialogue form, with at least two speakers addresing each issue.  This approach recognizes that there are many worthy perspectives from which these issues are addressed and diverse values involved in reaching personal conclusions.  The aim of the conference is to provide a safe place for discussing these different options in a way that highlights the values and traditions involved.  The conference is free and open to the publid.  It is hoped that all segments of the campus and wider community will participate.||10/28/2007||

49348|event_desc|This course will be an extension for those who participated in the beginning level of Constructing Web Pages to Support Your Classroom. We will continue exploring Internet resources; explore hot educational topics such as Internet safety and copyright laws. This course will focus mostly on the evaluation of existing WebQuests, modification of existing WebQuests to fit your curriculum needs, and creation of WebQuests from scratch. Students will be required to create a portfolio of web sites to use as classroom resources, and a WebQuest to use in their classroom, or a web page to publish their classroom information. Technology topics covered are WebQuests, iKeepbookmarks.com, Mozilla Composer, and FTP software. Completed student work will be published on the Internet.||10/28/2007||

49355|event_desc|Multiexceptional students are those who demonstrate behaviors that fit the criteria for giftedness and special education. They may be gifted with specific learning disabilities, or gifted and emotionally disturbed, gifted and ADHD, etc. The aim of this course is to review the relevant research pertaining to best practices for helping multiexcepational students succeed. The focus of the class is on practical strategies that apply this research to real situations and problems that school personnel face on a daily basis.||10/28/2007||

49363|event_desc|This class will provide a comprehensive update of the research of the social and emotional characteristics and needs of gifted students.  Topics include differences in the development of gifted youth, counseling needs, and characteristics of moderate and elite gifted students, parenting practices that yield different outcomes, preventing and reversing underachievement, peer relations and the twice-exceptional learner.  Also to be presented are guidelines for distinguishing normal gifted behaviors from serious behavioral concerns.  Emphasis will be on effective strategies for supporting optimal development and high performance.||10/28/2007||

49367|event_desc|The student will demonstrate receptive mastery of targeted, context-specific commands, questions, and statements in ASL. Students will be exposed to short narratives, stories, etc. in ASL that are told by the teacher and by Deaf users of ASL. Students will know the history of ASL, the Deaf Community, ASL and its relation to other forms of signing of the diagnostic continuum. Students will demonstrate receptive and expressive readiness for acquiring ASL by participating in at least 80% of the classroom exercises on receptive and expressive readiness. Students will demonstrate the ability to initiate, conduct, and terminate a short context-specific conversation with Deaf users of ASL other than the teacher with 80% or higher accuracy.||10/28/2007||
49368|event_desc|TRID 292-400 Private Pilot Ground introduces the student to the areas of knowledge required for an FAA private pilot certificate. Topics covered include: basic aerodynamice, aircraft systems, aircraft performance, airport operations, navigation and flight planning, aviation meteorology, FAA regulations, and aviation safety. The knowledge gained during this course will be applied and expanded upon during the co-requisite, AV 102- Private Pilot Flight.||10/28/2007||

49370|event_desc|This is an advanced course in ASL and is for students who wish to continue to work on their conversational skills in ASL.  We will start to interpret from taped material and will work on receptive skills. Students completing this course will be able to: 1) sign more fluently with a Deaf or Hard of Hearing individual who uses American Sign Language; 2) receive receptively ASL and to put it into proper English sentences; 3) increase the student's sign vocabulary; 4) gain more knowledge about Deaf culture; 5) increase the students signing skills; 5) learn to evaluate errors in signing work; and 6) improve on receptive skills.||10/28/2007||

TRID 292-401 allows students to apply the knowledge gained in the companion course, TRID 292-400- Private Pilot Ground.||10/28/2007||
49373|event_desc|TRID 292-402 provides the knowledge required for an FAA airplaine Instrument Rating. This rating trains pilot to fly and navigate the aircraft solely by reference to the instrumentation in the aircraft- this skill is required on any flight in clouds or low visibility. The instrument rating also gives pilots a higher understanding of navigation, the national airspace system, air traffic control, aviation meteorology, aircraft equipment, and flight planning considerations. The knowledge gained in the instrument ground school will be applied in the co-requisite, AV 202- Instrument Flight.||10/28/2007||
49374|event_desc|This is an advanced course in ASL and is for students who wish to continue to work on their conversational skills in ASL.  We will start to interpret from taped material and will work on receptive skills. Students completing this course will be able to: 1) sign more fluently with a Deaf or Hard of Hearing individual who uses American Sign Language; 2) receive receptively ASL and to put it into proper English sentences; 3) increase the student's sign vocabulary; 4) gain more knowledge about Deaf culture; 5) increase the students signing skills; 5) learn to evaluate errors in signing work; and 6) improve on receptive skills.||10/28/2007||
49375|event_desc|TRID 292-403 provides the student with the flight training and experience required for the FAA instrument rating. This rating allows a pilot to operate an aircraft solely by reference to instruments in clouds and low visibility. TRID 292-403 allows students to apply the knowledge gained in the companion course, TRID 292-402 - Instrument Pilot Ground||10/28/2007||

49407|event_desc|TRID 292-404 provides the knowledge required for the FAA multi-engine rating.  This rating introduces the pilot to multi-engine aircraft systems, equipment, operation, performance, flight planning, and emergency procedures.  The knowledge gained in the multi engine ground school will be applied in the co-requisite, TRID 292-405- Multi Engine Flight.    Co-requisite:  TRID 292-405 - Multi Engine Flight.  Prerequisites: TRID 292-400 - Private Pilot Ground, TRID 292-401- Private Pilot Flight, TRID 292-402- Instrument Ground, TRID 292-403 Instrument Flight, TRID 292 - Commercial Ground, TRID 292 - Commercial Flight; or FAA commercial pilot certificate with instrument rating.||10/28/2007||

49494|event_desc|Few events in American history have aroused such passion and controversy as General George Armstrong Custer's disastrous defeat at Little Bighorn on June 25, 1876. Now, relive that infamous abllet as you visit the Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument and Reno Benteen Battlefield. This stimulating week of instructions will include lectures, field trips, and living history with a visit to the famous Plains Indian Museum. Examine the history, heritage and way of life of the Plains Indians and their customs, art, and life. See Chief Plenty Coup's home and Interpretive Center. Each day you will begin in the mountain hamlet of Red Lodge which was once in the heart of Crow Country.||10/28/2007||

49497|event_desc|Adventure and true hands-on activities await you with lecture and special field trip over Beartooth Pass. Explore mountain meadows and learn to identify colorful alpine flowers and specialized plants of the thermal area. Enjoy breathtaking scenery. Explore Yellowstones rich cultural history, and its magnificent natural beauty. Learn about the Parks history, geology, and wildlife. An overnight field trip through the Park provides views of geysers, mountains, and wildlife. Guided easy hikes.||10/28/2007||
49498|event_desc|Enjoy a panoramic view of the Yellowstone River from the top of Pompeys Pillar, site of Clarks perfectly preserved signature. Study the background of the Lewis and Clark expedition and read selected portions of the journals. The Corps of Discovery experienced some of the most perilous and magnificent events of their journey in Montana. Learn how they survived enormous challenges with only primitive means and supreme analytical thinking. Study the scientific aspects of their journey with an emphasis on Clarks return trip via the Yellowstone River. Hear the story of Sgt. Pryors lost horses. An overnight trip to Great Falls includes Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center, the Great Falls and classic western art at C.M. Russell Museum.||10/28/2007||
49499|event_desc|Experience a breathtaking land relatively unchanged since the passing of Lewis and Clarks Corps of Discovery. Here the Corps of Discovery made its most significant geographic discoveries and faced its most serious challenges during their three year odyssey. Explore the history of the expedition from the hopes of President Jefferson, to the enduring bravery of the men and their scientific discoveries. Witness Montanas natural wonders, and see first hand some of Mother Natures challenges and dangers the explorers faced on a daily basis from white hater rapids, to the breathtaking mountains.||10/28/2007||
49500|event_desc|A wildlife adventure awaits you in Yellowstone as you travel through the Hayden and Lamar Valleys  watching for moose, buffalo, bears, wolves, birds and other animals. You will marvel at the wild beauty and learn about the environmental issues. Discover the mysteries of volcanoes, sculpted rocks, geysers and mud pots. Study the geyser basins and the secrets of Yellowstone Lake to learn how the geologic events and geological materials set the stage for ecosystem development. The Old West comes alive in Cody, Wyoming, where the people are friendly and the land is wild. Western legends surround you at the historic Irma Hotel, built by Buffalo Bill Cody. This western town offers endless activities for outdoor adventures, as well as art and history enthusiasts. At the base of a secluded mountain valley, 50 miles from Yellowstone, Cody is the gateway to spectacular scenery, and home to the Buffalo Bill Historical center, the foremost Western museum in the world.||10/28/2007||
49501|event_desc|Join us for an Old West adventure where the legends of Buffalo Bill Cody, Jim Bridger and other colorful characters live on. Relive your childhood image of the American cowboy and his horse, as you watch a gunfight and see real cowboys and cowgirls at the Cody Night Rodeo. Learn how homesteaders, ranchers, and cowboys impacted the growth of western states. Visit Shell Falls and look for bands of wild horses in the McCullough Peaks, as well as deer, antelope, and mountain lions, then on to Bighorn Canyon National Recreational Area, in search for Bighorn sheep and the Pryor Mountain wild horses. Top this with a full day excursion to Yellowstone Park seeing glorious scenery, geysers, Old Faithful, buffalo, bears, and berries. The Old West comes alive in Cody, Wyoming, where the people are friendly and the land is wild. Western legends surround you at the historic Irma Hotel, built by Buffalo Bill Cody. This western town offers endless activities for outdoor adventures, as well as art and history enthusiasts. At the base of a secluded mountain valley, 50 miles from Yellowstone, Cody is the gateway to spectacular scenery, and home to the Buffalo Bill Historical center, the foremost Western museum in the world.||10/28/2007||
49502|event_desc|Join us for adventure and fun in the Rocky Mountains! Let us show you spectacular alpine beauty, wildlife and an awesome mountain environment, as we travel over majestic Beartooth Pass to Yellowstone. Our instructors and guide share their knowledge of wildlife behaviors, habitats, and conservation efforts to make sure this program is a great learning experience. Venture onto lands where wildlife lives in natural habitats. Hear about threatened and endangered species, effects of environment degradation. Look for buffalo, deer, elk, bears, moose, birds, and wolves. Enjoy an overnight stay in Yellowstone Park. Your adventure begins in Red Lodge, surrounded by breathtaking mountains. Alpine beauty and entrance to the legendary Beartooth Scenic Byway. Enjoy its Western hospitality when you meet local cowboys, ranchers, artists and everyday folks. Red Lodge is noted for its cultural diversity and colorful past, where early 1900s era buildings house quaint stores, and art galleries. Indulge in fresh air and endless outdoor adventures; hiking, fishing, river rafting and horseback riding.||10/28/2007||

49549|event_desc|The Foundations of Effective Teaching Course examines the fundamental aspects of teaching and learning. This course identifies specific, core teacher behaviors that support good teaching. On-line access provides the opportunity to observe two accomplished teachers as they apply these behaviors in their classrooms.  The course focuses on two specific areas of research-based practice; classroom management and teaching effectiveness. The effective strategies highlighted in this course are based on research findings of the differences in practice that separate more effective and less effective teachers as defined by their ability to establish and maintain well managed classrooms and consistently produce significant gains in student achievement.||10/28/2007||

49555|event_desc|The student will demonstrate receptive mastery of targeted, context-specific commands, questions, and statements in ASL. Students will be exposed to short narratives, stories, etc. in ASL that are told by the teacher and by Deaf users of ASL. Students will know the history of ASL, the Deaf Community, ASL and its relation to other forms of signing of the diagnostic continuum. Students will domonstrate reeptive and expressive readiness for acquiring ASL by participating in at least 80% of the classroom excersises on receptive and expressive readiness. Students will demonstrate the ability to initiate, conduct, and terminate a short context-specific conversation with Deaf users of ASL other than the teacher with 80% or higher accuracy.||10/28/2007||

49583|event_desc|An Autumn adventure awaits you in Yellowstone  Americas Best Idea.  Wildlife is abundant in this land of spectacular natural scenery as summer gives way to fall. Walk in the footsteps of John Colter and see the unbelievable Geyser Basin and Old Faithful. Only three miles form the Northeast Entrance of Yellowstone National Park, Cooke City is a small alpine village with snow much of the year.  It sits in the heart of the Beartooth Mountains, surrounded by high mountain peaks and valleys.  Enjoy the slower pace of Cooke City with its rustic Old West atmosphere.  Once a mining town established in the early 1880s, it is now a friendly small village offering spectacular scenery, and great hiking and fishing.   Note: Be prepared for short hikes over uneven terrain.||10/28/2007||

49760|event_desc|This course provides an introduction to the avalanche phenomenon and what precautions will help keep you safe.  At the core of this course is how to recognize avalanche terrain, snow conditions, decision making, and basic rescue techniques.  This is a great first course for those new to travel in avalanche terrain and a great review for anyone who has some experience or prior training but feels they need a skills "tune-up."    This course includes an evening classroom session at MSU-Billings Downtown Campus and a field session on Red Lodge Mountain.  In order to get to the field site the group will meet at Red Lodge Ski Resort in the Bierstube at 9:30 AM Saturday morning.  From there the group will take a one way trip on the chair lift and then travel by ski, snowshoe, or split-snowboard to the field site.    Pre-requisites:  intermediate skiing, snowboarding with split board, or travel on snowshoes, and the ability to be in winter backcountry conditions for 4-5 hours.||10/28/2007||
49782|event_desc|Wildland fires in recent years have brought the ecology of fire in the West to national and international attention.  Bring the complex, interdisciplinary science of wildland fire to your students and other teachers by learning how to use the FireWorks educational trunk and curriculum.  This course contains 4 days of hands-on classroom and laboratory learning., discussions and lectures by fire researchers, and a field trip demonstrating forest restoration and field-based student evaluation.  Content focuses on ponderosa, lodgepole, and whitebark pine forests to demonstrate diversity in fire regimes, fire behavior, adaptations to fire, and successional patterns.||10/28/2007||
49793|event_desc|The Leopold Education Project (LEP) is a supplementary middle and high school curriculum correlated with the essays in Aldo Leopold's book, "A Sand County Almanac". This conversation classic, published in 1949, contains month-by-month descriptions of Leopold's experiences with the natural world in Wisconsin. The book also includes additional writings based on his various travels and conservation philosophies pertaining to a land ethic. Educators, who wish to expand their students' knowledge of nature as a basis for establishing a personal land ethic, will find this curriculum and its interactive lessons, a valuable source for achieving this goal. The curriculum materials can serve as multidisciplinary tools when teaching history, science, social studies, mathematics, language arts, and other subjects. "A Sand County Almanac" is a wonderful example of sound ecological understandings combined with excellent literary prose. Aldo Leopold was one of the early leaders in promoting wildlife management and the wilderness system in this country. He was also a forester, philospher, ecology/wildlife management professor, and prolific writer.||10/28/2007||

49933|event_desc|This course is a combination of two programs: Read Naturally is a fluency intervention and/or supplemental program based on current research on reading fluency. Ther Read Naturally program combines three strategies for improving fluency: teacher modeling, repeated reading and progress monitoring. REWARDS is a specialized reading program designed to teach intermediate and secondary students a flexible strategy for decoding long works and to increase their oral and silent reading fluency. REWARDS is an acronym for: Reading Excellence Word Attack and Rate Development Strategies.||10/28/2007||
49934|event_desc|This course is a combination of two professional trainings: Beginning Early Literacy and Language Skills: Literacy is a complex skill requiring the integration of three important building blocks including oral language, phonological processing, and print knowledge. This presentation will describe the powerful connection between language and literacy, developmental sequences, and the literate brain, discuss assessment issues and predictive indicators for literacy development and share specific strategies and highlighted activities that promote language and literacy in young children. DIBELS, an acronym for Dynamic Indicators of Basic Early Literacy Skills is a powerful measure of the critical skills that underlie early reading success. Supported by two decades of sophisticated research, these sipmle assessments predict how well children are likely to be doing in reading conprehension by the end of third grade. DIBELS assessment is a proven approach for taking 'vital signs' of reading health.||10/28/2007||

49951|event_desc|This course is intended to provide educators with instructional tools to change practice and promote student achievement through ongoing professional development. Participants will complete the (AFT) ER&D Managing Anti-Social Behavior Program. This course will offer a non-threatening, non-judgmental learning environment, providing opportunities for thoughtful discussion about teaching and learning with colleagues and researchers.  The course blends theory and practice into meaningful strategies that promote social skills development and academic progress.    The anti-social actions of a small but powerful percentage of students in school not only put their own academic success at risk, but also threaten the learning environment for the rest of the class. This course will present research on students who have emotional and behavioral problems and who are easily provoked. Participants will learn strategies to reduce and/or prevent the occurrence of disruptive outbreaks.||10/28/2007||

49965|event_desc|In this class we will find and share examples of folklore in our daily lives.  (Of course, we'll explore the time-honored tales and ballads, as well). Participants in this class will learn how to (1) recognize and (2) categorize various kinds of folklore with an eye toward (3) incorporating folklore in the classroom.  We will also (4) develop the critical analysis skills necessary to distinguish folklore from fakelore.  And we will (5) analyze folklore and folk items for their meaning in our culture.  Folklore and the analysis of folklore can be used to enhance critical thinking, multicultural understanding, storytelling skills and appreciation, and literary appreciation and creativity.||10/28/2007||

49968|event_desc|This workshop introduces IEP Team members to a student centered decision-making process used to identify individual student need for assistive technology. Many IEP teams are unsure how to address the issue of assistive technology in an IEP. Using case studies from their own situation, participants will 1) define assistive technology and IEP requirements 2) identify local and national resources 3) be introduced to the student centered decision-making process 4) match individual student need to appropriate technology 5) identify the different types of non-tech, low tech and high tech solutions 6) learn the difference between assistive technology and instructional technology. Groups of IEP team members and general educators are encouraged to attend. OPI renewal units are available.||10/28/2007||
49969|event_desc|This workshop introduces IEP Team members to a student centered decision-making process used to identify individual student need for assistive technology. Many IEP teams are unsure how to address the issue of assistive technology in an IEP. Using case studies from their own situation, participants will 1) define assistive technology and IEP requirements 2) identify local and national resources 3) be introduced to the student centered decision-making process 4) match individual student need to appropriate technology 5) identify the different types of non-tech, low tech and high tech solutions 6) learn the difference between assistive technology and instructional technology. Groups of IEP team members and general educators are encouraged to attend. OPI renewal units are available.||10/28/2007||

Students will demonstrate receptive and expressive readiness for acquiring ASL by participation in at least 80% of the classroom exercises on receptive and expressive readiness. 50207|event_desc|A drumming circle is a fully participating group experience that results in harmony, camaraderie and a feeling of wellness.  It is inclusive; no one is too young, too old, or too inexperienced to enjoy its benefits.  Using the circle as a metaphor, it is understood that everyone is an integral aspect of the whole process; everyone is equal and linked.  There is no audience, no right or wrong, no one person is in power and the power is shared.    When drumming is presented in a metaphorical context, it can be used as a tool for stress reduction, personal growth and over-all wellness.  Renowned drum circle facilitator SHARON SHANNON will lead this 2 hour circle.  A limited number of drums are available during class time for $10.  You may bring your own African Hand Drums.||10/28/2007||

50210|event_desc|Bring a curricular unit to spruce up by adding more interdisciplinary technology lessons.  Excite students with Internet resources, student technology projects and video. Best practices using video will be discussed.  Explore student-created examples of multimedia, clay animation and publications to improve understanding in the classroom. Activities can easily be adapted to any curricular area of study and software that participants already own.   During this class, participants will explore the possible curriculum connections they can make with technology projects.  They will learn how these projects were created and what resources are necessary for their successful implementation in the classroom. 50211|event_desc|This class is for those who have never drummed (or almost never) as well as for those whove had some drumming but feel more comfortable going at a slower pace. This rhythmic journey is both calming and exhilarating and while it can be a challenge at times, it is joyful and expressive. You will learn basic hand drumming techniques and to play multi-part African songs plus techniques for counting rhythm while exploring ways to feel rhythm. There is a strong emphasis on community as we gather around the drum in a celebration of diversity and unity. Renowned drum circle facilitator SHARON SHANNON will lead this 6 week course. 50294|event_desc|The Leopold Education Project (LEP) is a supplementary middle and high school curriculum correlated with the essays in Aldo Leopolds book, A Sand County Almanac. This conservation classic, published in 1949, contains month-by-month descriptions of Leopolds experiences with the natural world in Wisconsin. Educators, who wish to expand their students knowledge of nature as a basis for establishing a personal land ethic, will find this curriculum and its interactive lessons, a valuable source for achieving this goal. The curriculum materials can serve as multidisciplinary tools when teaching history, science, social studies, mathematics, language arts, and other subjects.||10/28/2007||

STEVE GILLIS has been teaching dance classes at the university level in Billings and Montana since 1974. His first students are now sending their children to his classes and some return with their kids just because it's still so fun! Steve not only teaches but has also served for the Big Sky State Games and many regional dance events. He is pleased to once again be included in offering these introductory series in dance with MSU-B.||10/28/2007|469|04/13/2006

In straightforward language, this class explains time-tested strategies that help you to make informed financial decisions. Whether your objective is to build a nest egg, protect your assets or preserve your lifestyle throughout retirement, this course helps you plan your future with confidence.  By attending Retirement Planning Today, you learn about the many ways to save for retirement as well as the advantages and disadvantages of each. You discover how to save money on taxes, manage investment risks and protect your assets from potential long-term health care expenses. Above all, this course shows you how to assess your financial situation and develop a personalized plan to achieve your retirement goals.||10/28/2007||

50802|event_desc|This course is intended to provide educators with instructional tools to change practice and promote student achievement through ongoing professional development. Participants will complete the (AFT) ER&D Managing Anti-Social Behavior Program. This course will offer a non-threatening, non-judgmental learning environment, providing opportunities for thoughtful discussion about teaching and learning with colleagues and researchers.  The course blends theory and practice into meaningful strategies that promote social skills development and academic progress.  The anti-social actions of a small but powerful percentage of students in school not only put their own academic success at risk, but also threaten the learning environment for the rest of the class. This course will present research on students who have emotional and behavioral problems and who are easily provoked. Participants will learn strategies to reduce and/or prevent the occurrence of disruptive outbreaks.||10/28/2007||

51381|event_desc|The unofficial national dish of Spain, paella, which takes its name from the shallow pan, or paellera, in which it is traditionally cooked, abounds in wonderfully aromatic flavors. 51382|event_desc|Back by Popular Demand with an added class !!!  Last semester students were thrilled to have the opportunity to learn the secrets of Chef Joel Torres of Caf Mabels in Laurel.  So Joel is back to do it all again, hell will walk you through the basics of Nuevo Latino Traditional cooking.  He will start with the flavor of Latina food, the Salsa - Verde, Fresca, Chimichili, Puerto Mojo, Cosida.  The second class will cover the many varieties of sauces, Moll, Friach, Stainer de Tela, Tomato, Fum.  The third class will teach the technique of authentic Mexican stir fry.  In the fourth class you will get to cook and sample the wonderful and unusual varieties of tacosno hamburger here.  Pot Roast & Cabbage, Pibil, Birria with Sweet Onions & Cilantro, and Fish tacos.  The fifth evening you will learn the art of Empanadas, both sweet (pineapple) and savory.   And finally  a brand NEW class, Joel will teach you to make Mabels famous Tamale!  Bring an appetite and a desire to learn the secrets of a master chef.   JOEL TORRES has a passion for food and everything fun about his culture.  You will learn more than cooking in these classes.|438|10/28/2007||

51457|event_desc|Pysanky is the ancient art of Ukrainian Egg Design.  In this class you will learn the traditional Russian method of intricately decorating eggs with wax and dye.    These eggs which are created during lent and given at Easter are an extraordinary expression of good wishes to the recipient.  You will have fun and learn an beautiful art form.  You will have time to create several eggs in this class.  In addition you will learn the history of this fascinating tradition.  Instructor Barbara Petak is known for her exquisite Ukrainian egg designs.  The President of the Ukraine has one of Barbaras eggs in his private collection.  Space is limited and in keeping with Russian tradition, Barbara only teaches this class during lent.|438|10/28/2007|438|10/26/2006

51473|event_desc|The student will demonstrate receptive mastery of targeted, context-specific commands, questions, and statements in ASL. Students will be exposed to short narratives, stories, etc. in ASL that are told by the teacher and by Deaf users of ASL. Students will know the history of ASL, the Deaf Community, ASL and its relation to other forms of signing of the diagnostic continuum. Students will demonstrate receptive and expressive readiness for acquiring ASL by participating in at least 80% of the classroom exercises on receptive and expressive readiness. Students will demonstrate the ability to initiate, conduct, and terminate a short context-specific conversation with Deaf users of ASL other than the teacher with 80% or higher accuracy.|438|10/28/2007|2435|01/11/2007

51492|event_desc|This is an advanced course in ASL and is for students who wish to continue to work on their conversational skills in ASL. Students completing this course will be able to: 1) sign more fluently with a Deaf or Hard of Hearing individual who uses American Sign Language; 2) receive receptively ASL and to put it into proper English sentences; 3) increase the student's sign vocabulary; 4) gain more knowledge about Deaf culture; 5) increase the students signing skills; 5) learn to evaluate errors in signing work; and 6) improve on receptive skills|438|10/28/2007|2558|05/25/2006

51584|event_desc|Thousands of animals in Montana have been affected by disasters.  Floods, blizzards, wildfires, earthquakes, hazardous material spills, train derailments, barn fires, propane line explosions can all require evacuation and are all realities in Montana.  If you think you will never have to evacuate unless you live in a floodplain or a coastal area, you may be tragically mistaken.  It is important that you make preparations to evacuate your family and your pets in any situation.  Disaster preparedness is particularly important for livestock because of the animals size and the requirements needed to shelter and transport them.  In the event of a disaster, proper preparation will pay off with the safety of your family, pets and livestock.  Animals depend on us for their well being, it is your responsibility to be prepared to evacuate or shelter your animals and keep them safe from harm.  There are simple steps that take less than 2 hours to learn that will help you prepare.  MSU-B Downtown and the Humane Society of the United States are proud to offer this very important class, free of charge.  Donations to the Humane Society of the United States are welcome but not required.|438|10/28/2007|2558|06/07/2006
51585|event_desc|Disasters have and will continue to strike Montana in the form of wildfires, floods, blizzards, hazardous material spills and large scale animal cruelty seizures.  This class will show how you, a public citizen, can help your community to respond to a disaster related event in which assistance is needed for emergency animal care which includes field rescue response and emergency sheltering.  You will learn that no matter what your present skill level is, there is a need for your talents to help both the animal victims and their owners in a time of crisis.  Whether you are a homemaker, school teacher, accountant, farmer or student you can help us and we can show you how.  In every disaster there is an animal component to be considered and everyone in Montana needs to prepare.  You can help us do that in your community.  MSU-B Downtown and the Humane Society of the United States are proud to offer this class free of charge.|438|10/28/2007|2435|01/05/2007

51770|event_desc|What do coaches, trainers and athletes know about high performance that we tend to ignore in education? They know that the transition from high ability to high achievement takes more than talent and hard work. It requires psychological readiness, or mental and emotional competencies that drive performance. They know that at the highest levels of achievement, its the inner game that makes the pivotal difference in performance. These competencies are not innate, but can be cultivated and shaped. Research in talent development across the domains of organizational psychology, athletics, performing arts, and education indicate that there are seven mental competencies associated with high achievement. The purpose of this class is to explore each of these competencies, their role in achievement, and determine ways we can effectively nurture them in students of all ages and abilities.|438|10/28/2007|2435|01/16/2007

51848|event_desc|Did you know that Montana has one of the highest suicide rates in the nation?  Research shows that the majority of people who consider suicide give warning signs preceding their attempt.  QPR (Question, Persuade and Refer) teaches people how to recognize these warning signs and to act vigorously to prevent a possible tragedy.  This one-hour training will be a life saving tool that will be taught by Preventive Health Specialists with Yellowstone City-County Health Department    |438|10/28/2007||
51849|event_desc|The purpose of this course is to prepare teachers to conduct the holistic scoring of student writing.  Through this workshop, teachers will 1) learn the rationale for Montanas holistic scoring in the Montana University System Writing Proficiency Assessment Program, 2) review prompts for persuasive writing, 3) read persuasive essays and select anchor papers, and 4) conduct the training and scoring session for other teachers.  In addition, teachers will use the Montana holistic rubric with their students and become familiar with other writing assessments used for college admissions, such as ACT and SAT.|438|10/28/2007|469|04/19/2006

51908|event_desc|This course is intended to provide educators with instructional tools to change practice and promote student achievement through ongoing professional development. Participants will complete the (AFT) ER&D Managing Anti-Social Behavior Program. This course will offer a non-threatening, non-judgmental learning environment, providing opportunities for thoughtful discussion about teaching and learning with colleagues and researchers.  The course blends theory and practice into meaningful strategies that promote social skills development and academic progress.  The anti-social actions of a small but powerful percentage of students in school not only put their own academic success at risk, but also threaten the learning environment for the rest of the class. This course will present research on students who have emotional and behavioral problems and who are easily provoked. Participants will learn strategies to reduce and/or prevent the occurrence of disruptive outbreaks.  |438|10/28/2007||

51916|event_desc|The week-long intensive will provide teachers with an introduction to arts integration- what it looks like and how it works  along with an in-depth exploration into the elements of music and drama and ways that they can enhance how a student learns to read.   Dr. Rosalind Flynns focus is on Curriculum-Based Readers Theater. Readers Theater is a rehearsed group presentation of a script that is read aloud rather than memorized. Teachers will learn how to plan, write, rehearse, stage and assess scripts with their students. Current research shows that repeatedly reading and rehearsing scripts based on curriculum content increases the likelihood that students will practice fluent reading, retain information and perform better on tests.  Marcia Daft teaches how integrating musical concepts (rhythm, best, meter, repetition) into the reading curriculum is effective in teaching word relationships, metric poetry and fluid and expressive reading.  Throughout the week, in small groups, everyone will develop lesson plans and present them to the entire group on the final day. Several opportunities will be provided for participants to observe the teaching artists demonstrating the arts integrated activities on a group of real students!   Recommendation: Bring several teachers from your school to make the experience more fun and encourage deeper understanding and learning.|438|10/28/2007||

51929|event_desc|Every human environment is unique; it is a text that has an author, an audience, and symbols that disclose intended and unintended meanings.  This interactive approach will study and unravel the mystery of how people use urban spaces when left utterly to their own devices, and will allow participants to read the urban landscape from historical, sociological, and interpersonal ways.  Using field experiences,  classroom discussions, and other activities, the participants will explore how the components and people interact in space and time to create the unique pace, rhythm, organization, and interaction that make each urban landscape unique.  For two weeks, participants will use Billings as an active learning laboratory to read the city in ways they had not contemplated before. Instructor:  Mona Mulhair, Clayton, California    U.S. Government and Politics:  The intent of this course is to increase understanding of the American political system, its framework, traditions and values with the goal of having each student pass the AP exam.  This course is concerned with the nature of the American political system, and its development over the past two centuries. Principle processes and institutions through which the political system functions, as well as some of the public policies which these institutions establish and how they are implemented will be examined in detail. 51947|event_desc|This Workshop will feature attendance at the Clark on the Yellowstone National Signature Event at Pompeys Pillar National Monument (July 22-25, 2006). 51953|event_desc|Thorough overview of the entire Lewis & Clark Expedition from a military perspective.  Course will include classroom instruction plus three field trips (three hours each) to local venues for outdoor instruction; The Billings Zoo (to discuss the science of the expedition), Pompeys Pillar (to discuss the significance of the expeditions passage through our local area), and to the Billings Armed Forces Reserve Center (for discussion of the military legacy of volunteer soldiers in Montana).  Participants will have the opportunity (but are not required) to participate in hands-on testing of period military firearms, tomahawk throwing, and primitive fire-starting.|438|10/28/2007|2558|07/07/2006

51957|event_desc|This Workshop will feature attendance at the Clark on the Yellowstone National Signature Event at Pompeys Pillar National Monument (July 22-25, 2006).  Participants will select from the many events/programs, including presentations on The Legacy of Clark, Native American Speakers, Tipi Village by Montana Tribal Tourism Alliance, Crow Indian Village, portrayals of William Clark, York, Sacagawea, John Colter, and others, Rendezvous tent of authors, Tent of Many Voices, and other presenters and activities (see the attached list).  This Workshop will help teachers better understand the people, events, context, and effects of the Lewis and Clark expedition, especially the journey of Clarks team down the Yellowstone, including the culture of Native Americans, natural history of plants and animals, music, and other aspects of the expedition, including subsequent fur trade and treaties.  Teachers will explore ways in which information connected with the expedition can be integrated into the classroom to enhance teaching across the curriculum.  The workshop will help teachers meet requirements of the Montana Indian Education for All Act.|438|10/28/2007|2435|05/22/2007

52048|event_desc|This class examines the many strategies that go into determining an equitable settlement.  We will talk about how to look critically at different settlement options and how each settlement option may affect each party, even when the bottom line looks the same.  We will talk about the different kinds of retirement accounts that are often included in a settlement.  And we will talk about child support  who pays it and why.  Well address the question:  Who should get the house?  We will also talk about the tax implications of child support, maintenance and asset division.  If you are already in the midst of the divorce process, now is the time to learn as much as you can about the decisions you must make.|438|10/28/2007|2558|07/14/2006

52096|event_desc|Traditional conflict resolution is about helping both sides compromise a little, so they can meet in the middle.  But having had to compromise is usually the exact source of their conflict.  Resolving the conflict can not be your direct goal because, many times, it will up the feeling and fear of future compromise.  To resolve a conflict each side needs a safe place to make peace with their losses before, during and after the conflict.  Without the safety to grieve your losses any new compromise feels like a further loss.  A new perceived loss will reinforce potential further conflict.  A big part of being able to resolve your losses is the safety to feel and see how ineffective and useless conflict is.  It also help you see that the biggest loss in loss is not the loss, but the defended reaction in how it was handled.  A premature resolution to a conflict will increase the very conflict the resolution is trying to reduce.  Emotional or physical war is not about the illusion of gain in your conflict, but about the reality of loss in your life.|438|10/28/2007|469|06/21/2006

52101|event_desc|Interest-Based Problem Solving is an issue-resolution process that addresses individual and group differences in a problem-solving environment.  Parties work together to solve problems through the sharing of information, creativity, flexibility and open communication rather than taking adversarial positions.  Participants will learn the six-step problem-solving method, the value of a structured problem-solving process, the critical elements of constructive dialogue, and how to construct durable, technically competent solutions.  Benefits of Interest-Based Problem Solving include:  issues are resolved quickly and closest to the stakeholders; relationships are enhanced; trust is built; meaningful and effective solutions are fostered through collaboration; and more constructive relationships result naturally.    |438|10/28/2007|2558|07/05/2006

52151|event_desc|Interest-Based Problem Solving is an issue-resolution process that addresses individual and group differences in a problem-solving environment.  Parties work together to solve problems through the sharing of information, creativity, flexibility and open communication rather than taking adversarial positions.  Participants will learn the six-step problem-solving method, the value of a structured problem-solving process, the critical elements of constructive dialogue, and how to construct durable, technically competent solutions.  Benefits of Interest-Based Problem Solving include:  issues are resolved quickly and closest to the stakeholders; relationships are enhanced; trust is built; meaningful and effective solutions are fostered through collaboration; and more constructive relationships result naturally.    |438|10/28/2007|438|04/05/2006

52153|event_desc|Traditional conflict resolution is about helping both sides compromise a little, so they can meet in the middle.  But having had to compromise is usually the exact source of their conflict.  Resolving the conflict can not be your direct goal because, many times, it will up the feeling and fear of future compromise.  To resolve a conflict each side needs a safe place to make peace with their losses before, during and after the conflict.  Without the safety to grieve your losses any new compromise feels like a further loss.  A new perceived loss will reinforce potential further conflict.  A big part of being able to resolve your losses is the safety to feel and see how ineffective and useless conflict is.  It also help you see that the biggest loss in loss is not the loss, but the defended reaction in how it was handled.  A premature resolution to a conflict will increase the very conflict the resolution is trying to reduce.  Emotional or physical war is not about the illusion of gain in your conflict, but about the reality of loss in your life.|438|10/28/2007|469|06/21/2006

52166|event_desc|What do coaches, trainers and athletes know about high performance that we tend to ignore in education? They know that the transition from high ability to high achievement takes more than talent and hard work. It requires psychological readiness, or mental and emotional competencies that drive performance. They know that at the highest levels of achievement, its the inner game that makes the pivotal difference in performance. These competencies are not innate, but can be cultivated and shaped. Research in talent development across the domains of organizational psychology, athletics, performing arts, and education indicate that there are seven mental competencies associated with high achievement. The purpose of this class is to explore each of these competencies, their role in achievement, and determine ways we can effectively nurture them in students of all ages and abilities.|438|10/28/2007|2435|03/20/2007

52240|event_desc|Allow me to introduce May Hasan Naji LaMotte.  May was born in Iraq and raised under the regime of Saddam Hussein.  The sentence raised under the regime of Saddam Hussein is an easy one to write, but those few words contain a lifetime of fear and the daily struggle to stay alive and out of prison.  May has fascinating and important stories to share about her life and the lives of her friends, family and colleagues both before and after Saddam.  May is passionate and articulate and wants to do everything she can to bring a better understanding of the Iraqi people to us here in the United States.  She is interested in seeing her native country thrive and become a culture that no longer fears self expression.  She hopes for a day when her family will have peace in their war torn country.  Please join May for an evening that will change how you think about the war, the Iraqi people, Islam, middle eastern customs, what it means to be a woman in the middle east.  You will have a better understanding of sectarian violence, and the American presence in Iraq from a regular persons point of view.  May will share some of her stories and answer your questions.  I look forward to seeing you there, Kim Schweikert, Program Coordinator.|438|10/28/2007|438|04/27/2006

52538|event_desc|Thousands of animals in Montana have been affected by disasters.  Floods, blizzards, wildfires, earthquakes, hazardous material spills, train derailments, barn fires, propane line explosions can all require evacuation and are all realities in Montana.  If you think you will never have to evacuate unless you live in a floodplain or a coastal area, you may be tragically mistaken.  It is important that you make preparations to evacuate your family and your pets in any situation.  .  In the event of a disaster, proper preparation will pay off with the safety of your family, and pets.  Animals depend on us for their well being, it is your responsibility to be prepared to evacuate or shelter your animals and keep them safe from harm.  There are simple steps that take less than 2 hours to learn that will help you prepare. 52582|event_desc|Much of the class will be taken up with language drills.  The goal of this course is to help students begin to understand Chinese and introduce them to Chinese characters. In the first session, Students will learn Chinese introductions, learn the four tones used in the Mandarin Language. Pronouns and counting will also be introduced.  They will be exposed to basic grammatical differences between English and Chinese. They will also learn about the diversity of language spoken in China.. Finally, they will be given tips about communicating with Chinese English speakers.     In subsequent classes, the instructor will provide handouts increasing the students vocabulary in both written and spoken Chinese, grammatical understanding and the ability to recognize key Chinese Characters. The over-all learning objective in the eight weeks is to help the students recognize simple Chinese statements, to be able to be understood by a Chinese speaker, to develop simple sentence construction and recognize the differences between Chinese and English sentence construction.  |2591|08/25/2006|2558|10/24/2006

52810|event_desc|The Leopold Education Project (LEP) is a supplementary middle and high school curriculum correlated with the essays in Aldo Leopolds book, A Sand County Almanac. This conservation classic, published in 1949, contains month-by-month descriptions of Leopolds experiences with the natural world in Wisconsin. The book also includes additional writings based on his various travels and conservation philosophies pertaining to a land ethic. Educators, who wish to expand their students knowledge of nature as a basis for establishing a personal land ethic, will find this curriculum and its interactive lessons, a valuable source for achieving this goal. The curriculum materials can serve as multidisciplinary tools when teaching history, science, social studies, mathematics, language arts, and other subjects. A Sand County Almanac is a wonderful example of sound ecological understandings combined with excellent literary prose. Aldo Leopold was one of the early leaders in promoting wildlife management and the wilderness system in this country. He was also a forester, philosopher, ecology/wildlife management professor, and prolific writer.        |438|10/28/2007|438|11/15/2006

52832|event_desc|Unix runs on all standard desktop computers. Through out the world most administered networks are UNIX-based. Since both Steve Jobs and Bill Gates know all about UNIX, both the Mac and PC use its modular and flexible approach to making these desktops do our bidding. After all these years, UNIX is still by far the most powerful system for computing or personal organization.     This course will put the potential of UNIX in your hands. Mac users already have a full-fledged UNIX available under the Terminal program. For PC users this is just a free LINUX installation away. The path to super-efficient management of your PC is through shell programs -- often called batch programs on steroids (named from the old DOS shell). This class will use UNIX to solve practical organization and data problems around storing, finding and manipulating data that arises through daily interactions.   |438|10/28/2007|438|11/21/2006

Mathematical topics and units that will be presented are Patterns & Relationships, Counting, Problem Classification, Situational Stories, Manipulatives, Recording, Instructional Lessons, Questioning, Planning for Instruction, Estimation, and Management. 52879|event_desc|The student will demonstrate receptive mastery of targeted, context-specific commands, questions, and statements in ASL. Students will be exposed to short narratives, stories, etc. in ASL that are told by the teacher and by Deaf users of ASL. Students will know the history of ASL, the Deaf Community, ASL and its relation to other forms of signing of the diagnostic continuum. Students will demonstrate receptive and expressive readiness for acquiring ASL by participating in at least 80% of the classroom exercises on receptive and expressive readiness. Students will demonstrate the ability to initiate, conduct, and terminate a short context-specific conversation with Deaf users of ASL other than the teacher with 80% or higher accuracy.|438|10/28/2007|438|05/21/2007

52881|event_desc|This is an advanced course in ASL and is for students who wish to continue to work on their conversational skills in ASL. 53054|event_desc|The Leopold Education Project (LEP) is a supplementary middle and high school curriculum correlated with the essays in Aldo Leopolds book, A Sand County Almanac. This conservation classic, published in 1949, contains month-by-month descriptions of Leopolds experiences with the natural world in Wisconsin. The book also includes additional writings based on his various travels and conservation philosophies pertaining to a land ethic. Educators, who wish to expand their students knowledge of nature as a basis for establishing a personal land ethic, will find this curriculum and its interactive lessons, a valuable source for achieving this goal. The curriculum materials can serve as multidisciplinary tools when teaching history, science, social studies, mathematics, language arts, and other subjects. A Sand County Almanac is a wonderful example of sound ecological understandings combined with excellent literary prose. Aldo Leopold was one of the early leaders in promoting wildlife management and the wilderness system in this country. He was also a forester, philosopher, ecology/wildlife management professor, and prolific writer.        |438|10/28/2007|438|02/06/2007
53056|event_desc|The course will consist of a two-week trip to Ireland, during which students will participate, on tour, in an agenda of scheduled activities related to Irish literature in particular, along with Irish history, social and political culture, and the arts more generally.  Each student will also complete two elective activities chosen by the student in conjunction with the instructor and will report back to the group informally about these two experiences.  The trip program will also allow students free time to explore other attractions of Ireland and its culture as they choose.|438|10/28/2007|438|07/08/2008
53058|event_desc|The goal of this course is to provide teachers with the content, teaching methods, and assessment strategies necessary to fully and effectively teach active citizenship. Participants will learn:   How students can make a difference in their community   Methods and procedures used in our political process   To promote competent and responsible participation in state and local government   How to develop a commitment to active citizenship    The workshop is correlated with the Montana State Social Studies Standards. Teaching Strategies will include:   Cooperative learning activities   Performance based assessment   Classroom methods    Lessons in the course can be used in many subject areas such as Social Studies, Language Arts, Math, Science, Service Learning, and Advisory Period. This project could be used in any grade from the 1st through 12th or even college.  It is also useful for clubs such as Boys and Girls Club and juvenile facilities.  |438|10/28/2007|438|07/08/2008

53088|event_desc|Certified Strength and Conditioning Specialist (CSCSs) are professionals who apply scientific knowledge to train athletes for the primary goal of improving athletic performance.  The conduct sport-specific testing sessions, design and implement safe and effective strength training and conditioning programs and provide guidance regarding nutrition and injury prevention.     |438|10/28/2007|438|06/20/2007

53098|event_desc|This intensive weekend educators course is designed to introduce K-12 teachers, naturalists, and resource educators to the theory and practice of place-based education. After receiving introductions to the group members and the concept of learning from the local land, the students will be guided in the exploration of the Rim Country Land Institute mixed grass prairie site. They will learn how to read the landscape as naturalists through demonstrations and practice. Discussions and reflection sessions will be held on related topics such as Gardners Multiple Intelligences; Inventorying the Land for Identifying Teaching Resources; Promoting a Sense of Wonder, Beauty, and Place; Aligning State Learning Standards with Local Places; Creative Curriculum Design; Land Management Issues and Activities; Service Learning; and Active Processing of Outdoor Experiences.      |438|10/28/2007|438|03/01/2007

The course will be especially useful for choir directors, band directors and other music educators who wish to supplement their schedule teaching guitar.  Topics will include:  Guitar Technique, repertoire, improvisation, music reading, ensembles and applying music theory to the guitar.  There will also be a survey of teaching resources and discussion on how to build a guitar program in public school settings.|623|10/28/2007|438|10/29/2007

53113|event_desc|'Day 1 - Participants will review Essential Understandings Regarding Montana Indians on OPI website. Through demonstration and interactive activities, participants will explore various themes, and historical and literary contexts in Native American literatures using Roots and Branches and the TBS Native Americans video series. Using literature written by Native Americans, participants will view, read, and listen to over fifty published books.  In addition, participants will practice 6-Trait Writing activities using some of these books.  Using samples from non-native authored books about Indians, participants will become acquainted with various stereotypes as well as the origins of these stereotypes.     Day 2 -  Participants will view and practice activities in developed units on Two Old Women by Velma Wallis and American Indian Stories by Zitkala Sa, as well as lessons using published books for children.  Each participant will receive a binder of workshop sections and reviews of books for children, activities, and lessons.  All Native American Literature books and resources listed on http://montana.ascd.org  website will be available for review and loan during the workshop.   This class qualifies for ''Indian Education for All''|438|10/28/2007|438|07/26/2007

53134|event_desc|This workshop is designed as a sequel to Purple Cow Poetry.  It is designed to be taken by teachers who have taught Purple Cow Poetry in their classrooms.  The format of the workshop will include sharing activities, ideas, and poems from Purple Cow Poetry, 6 Traits Writing ideas, and extended examples of previously taught poems. The goal of this workshop is to share the experiences and outcomes of the Purple Cow Poetry unit that was taught in the participants classrooms.  We will discuss successes and failures and brainstorm ideas for extensions of the unit.  We will also explore using the 6 Traits of Writing model in poetry.  The participants will leave with a portfolio of ideas for their classrooms and the knowledge to add to that portfolio what will fit into their curriculum      |438|10/28/2007|438|07/26/2007

53145|event_desc|AP English Literature and Composition:  The AP English Literature summer institute will cover ideas and methods to develop and teach an AP course that effectively prepares students for the exams.  Included will be consideration of ways to approach various genres of literature and techniques for dealing with college level writing both in and out of class.  Instructor: James Cross, Whittier, California    AP English Language and Composition:  The AP English Language and Composition course is designed to help students become skilled readers of prose written in a variety of periods, disciplines, and rhetorical contexts and to become skilled writers who can compose for a variety of purposes. By their writing and reading in this course, students should become aware of the interactions among a writer's purposes, audience expectations, and subjects, as well as the way generic conventions and the resources of language contribute to effective writing.:  Karla Walters, Bellevue, WA    AP Spanish Language:  This course will familiarize participants with the format and the requirements of the Advanced Placement Examination in Spanish Language.  It will also provide participants with pedagogical strategies,  classroom activities, materials and resources that will enhance student engagement and build the skills necessary for success on the examination and beyond.     Participants will receive many materials, including professional development materials from the College Board as well as others.  Participants will be encouraged to share their own successful strategies, activities and best practices, and may wish to bring copies of  favorite materials to share with fellow participants.  Participants are also encouraged to bring recordings of their favorite traditional and contemporary Hispanic music, as many strategies for using music in the classroom will be explored.  Instructor:  Marcia Arndt, NH    AP U.S. History:  This one week intensive seminar on teaching Advanced Placement US History will concentrate on giving new teachers a solid understanding of the AP process and providing them with training in preparation for teaching the course, while offering new and experienced teachers a wealth of free course materials, activities that help improve student writing scores, instruction in new approaches to teaching as well as information about upcoming revisions to the AP program.  Every effort will be made to make the week valuable and relevant for both new and experienced teachers, and one of the primary goals is to ensure that each teacher walks away from the seminar with new skills and curriculum that is immediately useable in their classrooms.      AP Biology: The Advanced Placement Biology Institute will help teachers plan and organize an Advanced Placement Biology course, including setting appropriate timetables, helping students organize materials and become more independent learners, and assisting teachers with techniques to enable their students to succeed on the AP Biology exam. The workshop will emphasize both study skills and laboratory experiences in required AP Biology topics.  Participants will set up, collect, and analyze data for many of the required labs.  Other sessions will include lectures and discussion of appropriate biological topics, using the Internet to help teach AP Biology, and a review of AP Biology testing procedures and previous exams.  Teachers are asked to bring a text appropriate for AP Biology, a course outline (if they have one), and at least one activity suitable for duplication and distribution to other participants. :Phyllis Nicholson, Sherman Oaks, CA  |438|10/28/2007|438|03/08/2007
53147|event_desc|This class will cover the current definition and research behind the term, Dyslexia.   Reading and spelling strategies based on Orton/Gillingham and other multisensory methods that have proven helpful for low readers will be covered.  Participants will explore ways to integrate these methods into the classroom.  Participants will also learn about some specific reading/spelling tutoring programs that are influenced by Orton/Gillingham procedures.  Accommodations for students with dyslexic type reading difficulties will also be covered, including those suitable for Middle and High School students.      |438|10/28/2007|438|07/09/2007

53150|event_desc|This course is designed for professionals, students and/or anyone interested in a comprehensive approach to maximizing performance while decreasing the negative impact of stress.  Students will develop a working understanding of psychophysiology, psychosomatic health, and research related to treatment and prevention strategies used to enhance emotional health. 53154|event_desc|Provides an opportunity to learn and utilize necessary skills for Camping, backpacking and outdoor recreation.  Includes   coverage of necessary equipment, orientation skills, basic first  aid techniques, wilderness safety, wilderness survival, and environmental care as related to outdoor experiences.  A   backpacking/camping experience in the Beartooth Mountain Range is included in the weekend dates of the course  Course Goals:                                                                                                                                                                                            1. To learn the proper skills necessary to provide a safe and enjoyable outdoor experience.  2. To be able to choose the proper equipment for an outdoor experience as well as maintenance,                selection, purchase and care of a wide variety of equipment used in outdoor education.  3. To demonstrate correct backpack planning and preparation.  4. To demonstrate usable survival skills; planning for survival, survival needs, and survival kits.  5. To demonstrate and use orienteering sills;  using maps and compass for navigation  6. To learn basic first aid techniques and safety education for dealing with injuries common to outdoor               experiences and risk management techniques used in outdoor/recreation settings  7. To learn and understand environmental concerns and care when involved in an outdoor/camping                setting     |438|10/28/2007|438|07/25/2007

53157|event_desc|The purpose of this course is to prepare teachers to conduct the holistic scoring of student writing.  Through this workshop, teachers will 1) learn the rationale for Montanas holistic scoring in the Montana University System Writing Proficiency Assessment Program, 2) review prompts for persuasive writing, 3) read persuasive essays and select anchor papers, and 4) conduct the training and scoring session for other teachers.  In addition, teachers will use the Montana holistic rubric with their students and become familiar with other writing assessments used for college admissions, such as ACT and SAT.     |438|10/28/2007|2435|05/17/2007

53178|event_desc|Thinking Mathematics is designed to help teachers and school systems improve math achievement by building on what is known about how students learn math. Research-based information teachers can use when making instructional decisions as well as a set of professional development units that help teachers explore with their peers the recommended approaches will be included. Mathematical topics and units that will be presented are Patterns & Relationships, Counting, Problem Classification, Situational Stories, Manipulatives, Recording, Instructional Lessons, Questioning, Planning for Instruction, Estimation, and Management. Each session will require reading and participation in activities.|438|10/28/2007|438|08/07/2007
