53205|event_desc|This week-long course provides teachers with an introduction to arts integrated teaching - the process of combining the study of an art form with the study of another academic subject - as well as an in-depth exploration of the integration of music and drama into the language arts curriculum.|438|10/28/2007|438|07/03/2007
53206|event_desc|The Institute begins with a review of the elements that are necessary to successfully integrate the arts with other curriculum subjects.    Level II participants will predetermine to focus on either Readers Theater or Word Painting, shadowing the workshop leader of their choice. Throughout the week, they will observe the workshop leaders working with the teachers and model teaching the students. They will be required to keep a journal documenting their observations and understanding of the work. They will also work with a group of students, teaching the same activities and strategies that they have learned from the workshop leaders. They will be critiqued and coached by the workshop leaders, resulting in an in-depth knowledge base of the materials covered throughout the week. When the week is over, they should be able to confidently teach the strategies and have a strong understanding of how to integrate either music or drama into the language arts curriculum. In addition, the Level II teachers will have the skills to coach other teachers to assist them in understanding how to integrate the activities into their classrooms.      |438|10/28/2007|438|07/03/2007

53210|event_desc|'A course for increasing mathematical content knowledge for kindergarten, first and second grade teachers.  Participants will:   Expand their knowledge and skills in mathematics content   Increase their understanding of how children learn mathematics   Extend their awareness of the relationship between number sense and algebraic thinking   Apply their learning to classroom situations             This course will be offered over a one-week intensive time frame, six  hours of instruction per day, for a total of 30 face-to-face hours, sponsored by Northwest Regional Educational Laboratory in Portland, Oregon.    Course Content:    During the Mathematics Summer Institute, teachers will engage in a variety of activities to deepen their understanding of number sense and algebraic reasoning. The activities include:   Engaging in mathematics   Analyzing video clips and examples of student work   Reading and discussing articles   Investigating research from Cognitively Guided Instruction (CGI)    The Institute will explore the following:   What is number sense and algebraic reasoning?   How do children develop number sense and algebraic reasoning?   What instructional strategies do teachers use to foster and support children's number sense and algebraic reasoning?  |623|10/28/2007|438|10/29/2007

53535|event_desc|Learning Through the Arts features a selection of professional development workshops in the arts that are offered throughout the school year and taught by local and Kennedy Center arts educators. The workshops fall into two categories: (1) in-depth study about an art form; or (2) hands-on exploration and learning of strategies using the arts, specifically visual art, drama, creative movement or music, to teach subjects across the curriculum. All the workshops will be a combination of lecture, discussion, hands-on activities and reflection.    Educators can select workshops from the year-long roster that interest them and match their teaching area and their students grade level. Participants must also attend the final reflection meeting on Monday, April 28, 2008, at 4pm and hand in a lesson plan created from strategies from the workshops that they have tried out in their teaching environments. A template for the lesson plan is provided. Each workshop is designated a certain number of hours. The final total number of hours (including the final meeting) must equal at least 15 hours in order to receive one credit.|3089|07/30/2007|438|07/18/2008
53543|event_desc|'Day 1 - Review Essential Understandings Regarding Montana Indians.  Through demonstration and interactive activities, participants will explore various themes, and historical and literary contexts in Native American literatures using Roots and Branches, poetry, excerpts from novels, short stories, traditional stories, essays, and the TBS Native Americans video series. Using samples from non-native authored books about Indians, participants will become acquainted with various stereotypes as well as the origins of these stereotypes.    Day 2 - Participants will view and practice activities in developed units on texts such as: James Welchs Killing Custer and Fools Crow, Velma Wallis Two Old Women, The Way to Rainy Mountain by N. Scott Momaday, Perma Red by Debra Earling, and selected poetry.    Each participant will receive a binder with copies of complete plans and activities for all the above units.  All Native American Literature books and resources listed on http://montana.ascd.org  website will be available for review and loan during the workshop. This class qualifies as ''Indian Education for All''.|438|10/28/2007|438|11/01/2007

53545|event_desc|'Day 1 - Review Essential Understandings Regarding Montana Indians.  Through demonstration and interactive activities, participants will explore various themes, and historical and literary contexts in Native American literatures using Roots and Branches, poetry, excerpts from novels, short stories, traditional stories, essays, and the TBS Native Americans video series. Using samples from non-native authored books about Indians, participants will become acquainted with various stereotypes as well as the origins of these stereotypes.    Day 2 - Participants will view and practice activities in developed units on texts such as: James Welchs Killing Custer and Fools Crow, Velma Wallis Two Old Women, The Way to Rainy Mountain by N. Scott Momaday, Perma Red by Debra Earling, and selected poetry.    Each participant will receive a binder with copies of complete plans and activities for all the above units. 53547|event_desc|'Day 1 - Review Essential Understandings Regarding Montana Indians.  Through demonstration and interactive activities, participants will explore various themes, and historical and literary contexts in Native American literatures using Roots and Branches, poetry, excerpts from novels, short stories, traditional stories, essays, and the TBS Native Americans video series. Creativity can be learned and this class will be an introduction to living the creative life no matter what you do.  Creativity isnt just for artists or designers or composers or the like. 53594|event_desc|Learning Through the Arts features a selection of professional development workshops in the arts that are offered throughout the school year and taught by local and Kennedy Center arts educators. The workshops fall into two categories: (1) in-depth study about an art form; or (2) hands-on exploration and learning of strategies using the arts, specifically visual art, drama, creative movement or music, to teach subjects across the curriculum. All the workshops will be a combination of lecture, discussion, hands-on activities and reflection.    Educators can select workshops from the year-long roster that interest them and match their teaching area and their students grade level. Participants must also attend the final reflection meeting on Monday, April 28, 2008, at 4pm and hand in a lesson plan created from strategies from the workshops that they have tried out in their teaching environments. A template for the lesson plan is provided. Each workshop is designated a certain number of hours. The final total number of hours (including the final meeting) must equal at least 15 hours in order to receive one credit.|438|10/28/2007|438|07/18/2008

Spindles have grown in popularity due to their portability, affordability and aesthetically pleasing materials and designs.  Youll learn about the variety of spindles available and will practice spinning using wool roving and a gentle, non-intimidating method that will make learning easy.  This course is suitable for those who have never spun and also for wheel spinners ready to take the hand spindling plunge.  You will receive a drop spindle, four ounces of roving (approx 150 yards of yarn) and easy to follow instructions to take home. 53919|event_desc|A search for the meaning of [or meaning in] life.  Join Professor Emeritus Walt Gulick in a discussion about Dennis Fords book The Search for Meaning: A Short History. Ford boils down the search for meaning to the bare essentials, showing the difference between viewing the world from a religious point of view and that of a naturalist, and comparing a scientific worldview to a philosophical one. Ford investigates the contributions of the Greeks, Kant, and William James, and brings the discussion up to date with contemporary thinkers. The answers provided by traditional religions to increasingly difficult questions have lost their currency for many.  But the reductive or rationalist answers provided by science and postmodernism are themselves rife with unexamined assumption.                     |3089|12/06/2007|3267|08/07/2008

COURSE CONTENT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES:   Goal: To provide educator teams with the background knowledge necessary to begin to plan to implement a Response to intervention model. 53987|event_desc|If you have always wanted to make better photographs but you think your camera is hindering your abilities to do so, this class will help. You will learn what kind of camera you need to acquire, to make the types of pictures you have always desired. From a pinhole camera to an 8X10 view camera all are just a tool and great photographs can be made with any type of camera. Everyone has a different idea of what he or she wants to photograph and purchasing the right tool will often help in making those pictures. Getting the image in the camera is the first step. Getting it out of the camera is the next. You will learn how to bring your files onto your computer and store the digital files on disc space. You will get ideas on slideshow programs and websites to display your photographs. You will then learn the beginning steps in selecting photo editing software and how to edit and color correct at a very basic level.  Once you have the image in your computer, crop it, color correct it, and save it as a new file you are now ready to take it to the printers. You will learn about some local businesses that can print your photos and make them as beautiful as real life. The instructors experience and passion for the trade will inspire you to shoot better pictures.                |438|12/18/2007|438|05/09/2008

You will learn how to use your new digital camera from shutter speeds, aperture and ISO to white balance and time exposures. This class will help you better understand your equipment so you will not have to worry about the camera and concentrate more on your subject. You will learn that if you are not absolutely sure of your exposure it is not a good idea to take the picture. The fundamentals of exposure and composition will be covered and you should leave with your camera knowing at least, where to look for the answer if you cannot remember how. Each girl who attends the tea will receive an American Girl paperback book and the chance to win other great American Girl prizes.  What a great way to celebrate being a girl!!  Children must be accompanied by at least one adult.  After the tea party enjoy a performance of ""Addy: An American Girl's Story"" at the Alberta Bair Theater.  Addy Walker is a hopeful 9-year-old girl growing up in slavery during the Civil War. Her life changes forever the day Poppa and her brother, Sam, are sold from their North Carolina plantation. Momma and Addy realize they must take the terrible risk and run before they lose each other, too. During their escape, Addy's courage helps save her and Momma as they face the terrifying road to freedom. When they finally arrive in Philadelphia, Momma finds work while Addy gets to attend school for the first time. Addy is thrilled to learn how to read and write, and she is grateful to find a true friend in Sarah. Building a new life in freedom isn't easy, and Addy desperately misses Poppa, Sam, and Esther. 54208|event_desc|Envisioning the Future of Arts Education is a four-day conference put on by the Kennedy Centers Education Department. It is the annual meeting for all of the approximately one hundred Partners in Education teams from across the United States. The schedule for the conference is attached. Each day of the conference features workshops, panel discussions and lectures from the group of presenters who are listed above. In addition to the listed agenda, participants will meet for breakfast, lunch and dinner throughout the week to network and collaborate with other arts organizations and school districts. One of the mornings (Thursday) is spent going to the offices of our two Montana Senators and one Representative and visiting with them and their staff about the arts and education work that our Billings/Laurel Partners in Education team members are doing in our communities. All the conferences sessions will include a combination of lecture, discussion, hands-on activities and reflection. Upon returning to Billings, participants will meet to evaluate and reflect on the conference and develop ideas for future arts education programs and advocacy.|335|02/26/2008|438|09/03/2008

54219|event_desc|Welcome to what I hope will be an enjoyable exploration of theatre and performance. Those of you who have an interest in, or experience with, live theatre will find that approximately 50% of this course will be dedicated to the study of that particular topic. That is as it should be, I believe, because the long and colorful history and traditions of theatre date back approximately 2500 years to the Golden Age of Greece, and still form the basis for most discussions within the larger context of performance.  For the purposes of this class, performance simply refers to a variety of activities that do not fall under the traditional heading of theatre. These might include music and dance performances, stand up comedy, film, cartoons, the circus, teacher/student interactions,  political performance, and many others too numerous to mention here. As we progress through this class, your own personal ideas about performance will be a valuable asset to our discussions. There is no absolute, all-encompassing definition of performance. The term is controversial and highly contested both in and out of academia. As an introductory level course, we will not spend a lot of time on performance theory (That subject is covered in Comt 350). Instead, we will read and/or view a wide variety of performances and talk about them. YOUR TEXTBOOK IS FOR THE PURPOSE OF ENRICHING YOUR PERSONAL BACKGROUND ON PERFORMANCE. THERE ARE NO TESTS IN THIS CLASS. Apart from suggested readings from your text, any additional classroom materials will be provided by the instructor.  |438|03/07/2008|438|09/03/2008
54220|event_desc|Project Citizen is a curricular program that promotes competent and responsible participation in state and local government.  It helps young people learn how to monitor and influence public policy.  In the process they develop support for democratic values and principles, tolerance, and feelings of political efficacy.  Students find a problem in their community that can be corrected with public policy, identify the responsible agency, create several alternative solutions, select the best policy, and develop an action plan to enact the needed legislation.|438|03/10/2008|438|12/08/2008

54288|event_desc|This intensive weekend educators course is designed to introduce K-12 teachers, naturalists, and resource educators to the theory and practice of place-based education.  After introductions within the group and to the concept of learning from the local land, the students will be guided in the exploration of the Rim Country Land Institute mixed grass prairie site.  They will learn how to read the landscape as naturalists through demonstrations and practice.  Discussions and reflective sessions will be held on related topics such as Gardners Multiple Intelligences; Inventorying the Land for Identifying Teaching Resources; Promoting a Sense of Wonder, Beauty, and Place; Aligning State Learning Standards with Local Places; Creative Curriculum Design; Land Management Issues and Activities; and Active Processing of Outdoor Experiences.  |3179|03/28/2008|438|01/09/2009
54289|event_desc|Sense-of-place education or place-based education is an approach that is garnering considerable nationwide attention as teachers look for new ways to make educational experiences more meaningful and relevant for their students.  Teacher training workshops that focus on sense-of-place curricula can be adapted to any community to fit with state and national science standards.  This workshop focuses on means by which teachers can inspire students and lift education to a more meaningful level by using bioregional, place-based, field oriented, experiential, and environmental education instruction.  In this workshop teacher will develop instructional units that are based in the local schoolyard, community, watershed, or other outdoor area  and, most importantly, in a personal way. |3179|03/28/2008|438|01/08/2009
54290|event_desc|Sense-of-place education or place-based education is an approach that is garnering considerable nationwide attention as teachers look for new ways to make educational experiences more meaningful and relevant for their students.  Teacher training workshops that focus on sense-of-place curricula can be adapted to any community to fit with state and national science standards.  This workshop focuses on means by which teachers can inspire students and lift education to a more meaningful level by using bioregional, place-based, field oriented, experiential, and environmental education instruction.  In this workshop teacher will develop instructional units that are based in the local schoolyard, community, watershed, or other outdoor area  and, most importantly, in a personal way.|3179|03/28/2008|438|01/08/2009

54359|event_desc|The key to capturing the decisive moment in a photograph is anticipation. Every photograph tells a story. In this class David will show you how he tells stories with his photographs. Looking at examples are always a good way to get ideas so you can go out and make a better photo than the illustrated idea. This class will teach you to be more aware of your environment when making images and teach you to see composition rather than just point and shoot. Depth of field will be covered extensively as will time exposures and special effects photography like shooting lightning and fireworks. This class is for the more experienced photographer. The student must know the equipment they are working with and must be able to concentrate entirely on composition. Assignments will be given and photos will be critiqued by the entire class. 54429|event_desc|Mornings: This workshop is designed to use place value as a tool to understand the four basic arithmetic operations. Using a monetary approach and calling numbers by their correct place value names, the participants will find many creative and humorous ways to teach the basic math concepts. Developmental theory, multiple intelligences and different learning styles will be emphasized which should enable teachers to help all students, including those who are dyslexic and math anxious, to understand math concepts from the concrete stages to the abstract. The final outcome of the workshop is to understand that arithmetic is answering the question whereas mathematics is questioning the answer.  Afternoons: Everything we know about geometry , mathematics, and all spatial arrangement and organization of matter is demonstrated by cutting into the wholeness of the sphere. When we cut the sphere we have pieces, parts, and fragments. It is no longer whole. When keeping the wholeness of the sphere and compressing it to a flat plane nothing is lost, all the spatial information is compressed into a flat circle disc.      |438|04/24/2008|438|09/01/2008

54464|event_desc|Autism is a complex developmental disability that typically appears during the first three years of life. Autism is a neurological disorder that affects the normal functioning of the brain, impacting development in the areas of social interaction and communication skills. This high incidence of autism is presenting some dramatic challenges for educators, medical professionals and families. A recent study indicates that 86% of parents of autistic children divorce.  You will hear from medical professionals, therapists and parents abut clinical and non-clinical treatments tht are having some sucess in treating the disease. We will discuss everything from swimming with dolphins to Neuroimaging and Morphometric Analysis. The only way to have an impact is to work as a community, combining the resources of educators, medical professionals, therapists, counselors and parents. This conference is open to all.|438|05/07/2008|438|12/31/2008

54466|event_desc|Learning Through the Arts features a selection of professional development workshops in the arts that are offered throughout the school year and taught by local and Kennedy Center arts educators. The workshops fall into two categories: (1) in-depth study about an art form; or (2) hands-on exploration and learning of strategies using the arts, specifically visual art, drama, creative movement or music, to teach subjects across the curriculum. All the workshops will be a combination of lecture, discussion, hands-on activities and reflection.    Educators can select workshops from the year-long roster that interest them and match their teaching area and their students grade level. Participants must also attend the final reflection meeting on Monday, April 28, 2008, at 4pm and hand in a lesson plan created from strategies from the workshops that they have tried out in their teaching environments. 54488|event_desc|Learn the basics of digital photography using your point and shoot cameras or your single lens reflects cameras. If you don't have a camera or if you don't like the camera you have, this class will teach you how to select and purchase the correct camera for your specific type of photography. It might even teach you to like the camera you have. We will start with camera handling, teaching exposure controls, composition and design and lighting. Sometimes great pictures start with great ideas. You will learn some techniques in making better photographs by making these ideas into pictures. You will learn how to look for moments and anticipate when a good picture is about to happen. The instructor will help you shoot photographs in class so you have images to work with on the second day. Getting the photos in the camera is the first step, getting them on you computer is the next. On day tow you will learn how to put these images in your computer and manipulate them with image editing software like Photoshop. You will learn how to tone the images, fixing exposure mistakes and cropping the images into eyecatching works of art all while sitting at your computer. For those who make pictures in schools for yearbooks and newsletters, you will learn what to look for to make better school photos and how you may use them as teaching tools.  |438|05/28/2008|438|09/11/2008

Getting the photos in the camera is the first step, getting them on you computer is the next. On day tow you will learn how to put these images in your computer and manipulate them with image editing software like Photoshop. You will learn how to tone the images, fixing exposure mistakes and cropping the images into eyecatching works of art all while sitting at your computer. For those who make pictures in schools for yearbooks and newsletters, you will learn what to look for to make better school photos and how you may use them as teaching tools.|438|05/28/2008|438|09/12/2008

54525|event_desc|This course will provide the student with an opportunity to study principles of child development as they relate to providing a safe and healthy learning environment for child care settings.    COURSE CONTENT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES  The student will demonstrate an understanding of key concepts and practices in:  1. How to plan safe activities by taking into account childrens developmental levels and likely behaviors.  2. How to create and maintain safe classroom and playground environments.  3. Review what to do in case of a medical emergency.  4. Learn safe practices for taking children on field trips.  5. Develop and model good safety habits.  6. How to involve preschool children in developing safety rules for their classroom.  7. How to develop a safety curriculum.  8. How to set up a safe environment for children with special needs.  9. Develop a sound knowledge base regarding heal, nutrition and oral hygiene.  10. Carry out routine practices that will prevent illness and promote good health and nutrition.  11. Establish guidelines/policies regarding how to handle health issues/record keeping system.  12. Incorporate activities that teach children and families about health, oral/dental hygiene and nutrition.  13. Recognize indicators of abuse and/or neglect and follow the reporting policy mandated by the state.  14. Keep oneself healthy and model appropriate wellness behaviors for children and their parents.  15. Set up an environment that takes into account the behavioral characteristics, needs and interests of different age levels.  16. Develop a well-balanced daily schedule.  17. Set up an outdoor play and learning environment.  18. Ensure that the learning environment works for adults as well as for children.  |438|06/24/2008|438|09/12/2008

54616|event_desc|A Framework for Understanding Poverty  discusses how poverty impacts learning, work habits and decision making.  The reality of being poor brings out a survival mentality and turns attention away from opportunities taken for granted by everyone else.  Most teachers today come from middle-class background.  In an educational setting, economic class differences create conflict and challenges for both teachers and students alike.  Designed for educators at all levels but helpful to counselors administrators and support staff, this seminar provides practical, real-world support and guidance for overcoming barriers and helping others succeed    Learning Structures will convey how to build cognitive capacity and speed the learning process.  Its not intelligence or potential that many struggling students lack, but rather the cognitive structures so vital to effective learning and academic success.  Students from poverty especially often miss out on these mental building blocks .  Packed with powerfully effective, easy-to-use strategies based on Dr. Ruby K. Paynes book Understanding Learning: the How, the Why, the What  this seminar hands you tools to help students learn vital content while building new cognitive abilities into their brains.  |438|08/12/2008|438|11/17/2008

54619|event_desc|Though he never physically ventured beyond the Virginia Blue Ridge, Jefferson had a life-long commitment to supporting western exploration and asserting American claims to western lands. Jeffersons decisions shaped the American West profound and sometimes controversial ways that are still felt today.|3267|08/13/2008|3590|10/23/2008

54623|event_desc|Why should all Americans care about the Ten Commandments?  What role do they have in contemporary  America? Join Professor Emeritus Walt Gulick in a discussion about Chris Hedges, a former foreign correspondent for the New York Times and Harvard Divinity School graduate, book.  Explore how commandments hold our communities together. "They lead us to love, the essence of life," writes the author. Hedges believes that the commandments hold out to us the possibility of love -- and love means living for others. The commandments are guideposts that bring us back to the right path, he writes. They call us to sacrifice. Compellingly, he urges us to abandon the culture of self; to live "not by exalting our life but by being willing to lose it."  Please purchase the book and read the Preface first chapter prior to the first day of class|3267|08/13/2008|3590|11/17/2008

You'll also hear the warming stories of two "ladies of the night" with hearts of gold, and the Christmas celebrations at the old library. Next we'll tour the historic avenues, with fabulous old homes, an aura of the past, and Christmas Wreath Lane, a tradition begun by neighbors in the 1960s.  Must Register by December 9. 54648|event_desc|The Fifth Annual Kids, Computers & More! computer camp will be held December 29 - 30, 2008 at the MSU Downtown Campus.  The two day event is a partnership between Montana State University Billings and Computer 4 Kids.    During camp the kids will work with staff and volunteers and learn to assemble a computer.  They will learn how to install software and how to connect printers and CD drives, and they will learn to identify and correct basic hardware problems.  The curriculum also includes a lesson in basic word processing and a course on basic electrical safety.  In an effort to maximize the positive impact of this camp only one registration per household is allowed.    This event is open to middle school kids. Parents can drop their children off between 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. both days.  The fun will begin at 9:00 a.m., and conclude at 4:00 p.m. each day.  Parents should prepare a sack lunch and snacks for their children both days.  Once the students arrive at the Downtown Campus, they will not be allowed to leave the campus facilities unsupervised. 54697|event_desc|The Indians swarmed from everywhere, coming across the river and up into the gullies. as the Indians closed in, Custer ordered his men to shoot their horse and stack the carcasses to form a wall, but they provide little protection against arrows. 54717|event_desc|This course will teach the basics of digital photography starting with the camera, leading into exposure and composition and ending with photo-computer manipulation. The instructor, who is a professional photographer and photojournalist of 25 years will instruct through examples and demonstrate concepts by helping the students create photographs in class.  This course will teach the beginning concepts of digital photography starting with the different types of cameras. Students will be instructed on what kinds of cameras and photography equipment is available for various types of photography. The needs of the students will be different and so will the tools or the cameras. The course will continue into the concepts of exposure and how the operator must control the settings on the camera to obtain an optimum file or a photograph sufficient for printing. Moving on, the instructor will explain through examples, the concepts of composition, what makes a good photograph and the art of seeing through focal lengths. Photographs are captured moments in time. Moments are fleeting and must first be anticipated for the photographer to capture them. As the course moves forward the students will learn how to anticipate a moment and then capture that moment to be recorded as a file or photograph. The best way to learn photography is to watch a professional work and glean ideas. The instructor will demonstrate portrait photography in class and will take the students away from class into the field helping them make their own photographs. They will be instructed and evaluated on exposure and composition in the field. The students will be brought back into the classroom and their photographs will be put into the computer and viewed and critiqued. The very basic concepts of Photoshop or photo-computer manipulation will be demonstrated. This is a very important step in finishing up a digital photograph that will later be viewed on a computer or displayed in print.                 |438|09/25/2008|438|01/21/2009

54735|event_desc|Project Citizen is a curricular program that promotes competent and responsible participation in state and local government.  It helps young people learn how to monitor and influence public policy.  In the process they develop support for democratic values and principles, tolerance, and feelings of political efficacy.  Students find a problem in their community that can be corrected with public policy, identify the responsible agency, create several alternative solutions, select the best policy, and develop an action plan to enact the needed legislation.   The Citizen and the Constitution is a curricular program that promotes the understanding of our constitution and government.  It promotes the understanding of the foundations of our government and the way our representative democracy influences our lives.  Representative Democracy in America materials are developed by the Center for Congress at Indiana University, National Conference of State Legislators, and the Center for Civic Education to enrich the study of our government.  We will also include Foundations of Democracy, Indian Ed for All, and civic education through literature.  Teleconference or web based conferences are being arranged with The Library of Congress and The National Archives.  |335|10/02/2008|438|09/04/2009

He cant bear to part  with the dog, but hes having more and more trouble finding people who are willing to  keep the place clean for any amount of money!  Mrs. Mini, however, has heard about your Personal Assistant robot through a friend,  and wants to know if the robot could perhaps be adapted to serve as a robotic  housekeeper for the Minis and their dog.     Come and help us build and program this robot and maybe you can even learn to program one of your own to clean your room.    Students taking this 3 day beginning programming course will use a Lego Mindstorm Robot along with the Lego Mindstorm program to complete the project above as a team. Today, however, we are in midst of a crisis: Too few of our adults are prepared for the jobs of the future. Too many potential workers are dropping out of school. 54785|event_desc|Thinking Mathematics is designed to help teachers and school systems improve math achievement by building on what is known about how students learn math. 54798|event_desc|Surveys world art from prehistory to the present day with the objective of developing a critical understanding of art forms in their historical and cultural context. Students will understand the basic chronology and philosophies of the Western European art historical tradition, as well as gain insight into the visual cultures of East Asia, South Asia, Africa, the Pacific Islands, and the Americas.  They will be able to identify important concepts, monuments and artists.  They will be introduced to the fundamentals of writing about works of art and architecture. They will also be able to analyze the factors leading to the development of art historical traditions with an eye to the roles of gender and ethnicity.  |438|11/24/2008|438|07/28/2009
54799|event_desc|MSUBs General Education Curriculum is designed to instill specific outcomes. As part of the General Ed Curriculum, this course aims to develop the following knowledge, skills, and abilities. Expression and Receptive Skills (competence in listening, speaking, writing, reading, and observing), Critical Thinking (the ability to develop, analyze, appreciate, and/or challenge a reasoned argument), and Reflexive Awareness (the ability to monitor and communicate ones thought processes).  Introduction to Public Speaking is a performance course designed to give you basic rhetorical theory and its application in a variety of speech situations. This is an opportunity for you to engage in public dialogue. You will participate in the full process of organizing, delivering and critiquing several speeches: selecting a topic, analyzing the audience, researching and organizing information, presenting the speech and using visual aids. This course will also emphasize the importance of effective listening skills, critical thinking, and address the topic of performance anxiety.  |438|11/24/2008|438|07/28/2009

54807|event_desc|Join us for an evening of fun and entertainment as Randy Pugh takes us through the life stories and films of two beloved Montana legends: Gary Cooper and Myrna Loy. Both stars were born in Montana early in the 20th century and rose to the top of their profession in the Golden Age of Hollywood in American filmmaking. Gary Cooper was often characterized as the epitome of the "common man" or "average Joe." Myrna Loy was considered by critics and audiences to be "the perfect wife." This common touch, and the obvious photogenic qualities of both ,pgqstars will be explored through the viewing and discussion of selected scenes from some of these actors' most famous and award-winning films. Enjoy some popcorn and coffee as we explore the lives of the two actors who made such an impact on American film!|3590|11/26/2008|3590|04/01/2009
54809|event_desc|This course will teach the basics of digital photography starting with the camera, leading into exposure and composition and ending with photo-computer manipulation. The instructor, who is a professional photographer and photojournalist of 25 years will instruct through examples and demonstrate concepts by helping the students create photographs in class.  This course will teach the beginning concepts of digital photography starting with the different types of cameras. Students will be instructed on what kinds of cameras and photography equipment is available for various types of photography. The needs of the students will be different and so will the tools or the cameras. The course will continue into the concepts of exposure and how the operator must control the settings on the camera to obtain an optimum file or a photograph sufficient for printing. Moving on, the instructor will explain through examples, the concepts of composition, what makes a good photograph and the art of seeing through focal lengths.    |438|11/26/2008|438|03/03/2009

55092|event_desc|Pysanky is the ancient art of Ukrainian Egg Design.  In this class you will learn the traditional Russian method of intricately decorating eggs with wax and dye.  These eggs which are created during lent and given at Easter are an extraordinary expression of good wishes to the recipient.  You will have fun and learn a beautiful ancient art form.  You will have time to create several eggs in class.  In addition you will learn the history of this fascinating tradition.  Instructor Barb Petak is known for her exquisite Ukrainian egg designs.  The Ukrainian Ambassador has one of Barbaras eggs in his private collection.  Barb only teaches this class during lent to follow the ancient tradition.  Space is limited. The steadier your hand, the more intricate the designs you can create.    |438|02/23/2009|438|04/08/2009
55093|event_desc|Creative Connections consists of a series of interactive, hands-on workshops that focus on using elements of drama, creative writing, and visual art to build student comprehension across the curriculum. Participants will be led through sequential and scaffolded instructional techniques for using the arts and be able to observe the workshop leaders demonstrating the techniques on a group of students. Activities will focus on elements from the Montana Indian Education for All curriculum. On the last day, everyone will connect the strategies into unit of study that focuses on their subject area. 55197|event_desc|This course is an introduction to the amazing world of biology for those of you who do not want to become professional biologists. We are embarking on what I think is a fascinating tour of the major fields of modern biology. We will start with the most fundamental components of life, the important biological molecules (like protein and DNA) and the structure of cells. We will then learn about the processes that keep cells alive, how cells reproduce, why organisms are similar...yet different, and finally end with the broader perspective provided by evolution, diversity and ecology. Through this course I hope you will begin to appreciate the incredible beauty and complexity of the living world. However, this course is not just about learning biological concepts. It is also about learning how biology affects your life. It may not be apparent to you now, but biology affects your life in both profound and subtle ways. Thus, you will spend a fair amount of time learning about many important biological issues (human disease, genetic engineering and stem cells to name only a few) that actually do have a direct or indirect impact on the quality of your life.|438|03/30/2009|438|04/24/2009

55205|event_desc|This course will teach the beginning concepts of digital photography starting with the different types of cameras. Students will be instructed on what kinds of cameras and photography equipment is available for various types of photography. The needs of the students will be different and so will the tools or the cameras. The course will continue into the concepts of exposure and how the operator must control the settings on the camera to obtain an optimum file or a photograph sufficient for printing. Moving on, the instructor will explain through examples, the concepts of composition, what makes a good photograph and the art of seeing through focal lengths. Photographs are captured moments in time. Moments are fleeting and are better to be anticipated for the photographer to capture them. As the course moves forward the students will learn how to anticipate a moment and then capture that moment to be recorded as a file or photograph.|335|03/31/2009|438|08/21/2009

55217|event_desc|Mornings: This workshop is designed to use place value as a tool to understand the four basic arithmetic operations. Using a monetary approach and calling numbers by their correct place value names, the participants will find many creative and humorous ways to teach the basic math concepts. Developmental theory, multiple intelligences and different learning styles will be emphasized which should enable teachers to help all students, including those who are dyslexic and math anxious, to understand math concepts from the concrete stages to the abstract. The final outcome of the workshop is to understand that arithmetic is answering the question whereas mathematics is questioning the answer.  Afternoons: Everything we know about geometry , mathematics, and all spatial arrangement and organization of matter is demonstrated by cutting into the wholeness of the sphere. When we cut the sphere we have pieces, parts, and fragments. It is no longer whole. When keeping the wholeness of the sphere and compressing it to a flat plane nothing is lost, all the spatial information is compressed into a flat circle disc.      |438|04/02/2009|438|08/19/2009

55226|event_desc|"The event will begin with girls participating in an expo. Each girl will receive a certain amount of money and will be allowed to participate in various activities. The girls will travel from booth to booth and will decide what activities to engage in based upon the amount of money that they have to spend. The one day expo will also include a key-note speaker and luncheon. The first day will be a full day.  The rest of the week will be a half-day, morning camp set in downtown Billings. The girls will participate in the CentsAbility Curriculum. Various community members and speakers will present throughout the week regarding: financial literacy, career opportunities and college preparation opportunities. You will leave with a better understanding of yourself while developing self-awareness, self-expression, and self-confidence!  Just bring YOURSELF  The content of this course emphasizes that Art comes from the Heart and is a way of knowing who we are.  No prior training is required to be creative.  It is a way of expressing what words cannot.  Art is for everyone.  There are no rules for creating!  Creativity is the ability to bring something new into existence.  This is a chance for students to explore without judgment by having fun while utilizing the basic elements and principles of art.  Studies have found that creative people are more independent, autonomous, self-sufficient, emotionally sensitive, assertive, self-accepting, resourceful, adventurous, and risk taking!  The creative process can create self-esteem, self-assurance, increase sensitivity, understanding of self, and enhance the quality of life! The historical mission of Indian  education (i.e., commitment to cultural preservation and revitalization;  enhancement of student well-being; the alleviation of low achievement  and high attrition) provides the context for the seven themes (diversity,  identity, history, treaty/reservation, Montana Indian schools,  stereotyping and sovereignty). 55373|event_desc|The concept of Gracious Space was developed through the Center for Ethical Leadership (www.ethicalleadership.org) and is being used by organizations and groups all over the country.  The concept is to create a safe atmosphere that contributes to relationship building.  By creating a shared vision for your group it is more likely to be productive and foster healthy and strong relationships.  Members learn to work together cooperatively despite differences in their age, gender, race or ethnicity.  All ideas are valued.  Gracious Space is not conversation or debate in the absence of conflict or tension; participants learn ways to work through difficult and challenging conversations through mutual respect.  The concept has been used successfully in many arenas including health care, government, community, non-profit groups and schools.  Practitioners of this philosophy find they are less judgmental, better listeners and more able to be open.  The result is an increase in productivity, creativity, and the opportunity for new understandings of others.  |335|04/30/2009|438|11/13/2009

55438|event_desc|We will explore the  FOLLOWING ISSUES that THREATEN  our kids everyday:   Bullying in schools is a worldwide problem that  can have serious negative consequences for the  general school climate and for the right of students  to learn in a safe environment without fear.  Bullying can also have negative lifelong  consequences--both for students who bully and for  their victims.   Cyberbullying is when a child, preteen or teen is  tormented, threatened, harassed, humiliated,  embarrassed or otherwise targeted by another  child, preteen or teen using the Internet,  interactive and digital technologies or mobile  phones.   If you google Teen Cybersex you will find  2,160,000 sites.   When gangs exist in a community, they can  seriously impact schools, using them as  recruitment centers and claiming them as gang  territory. A report issued by the U.S. Departments  of Education and Justice found that the percentage  of students reporting gangs at school nearly tripled  between 2001 & 2005. This report also found a  strong correlation between the presence of gangs  and both guns and drugs on school campuses   Suicide is the third leading cause of death in  individuals between the ages of 10 & 19 in the  United States.  ese are serious topics none of us want to admit  could happen in our schools, our community, or  our families. But they do. Join us for this two  day event to explore how we can work together as  educators, parents, and professionals to be  informed, learn prevention methods and most  importantly how to talk to our kids about these  issues so that we can create Safe Schools and a  Safe Community for them to grow up in.|438|05/21/2009|438|11/23/2009

55457|event_desc|This is a camp that is designed to teach young kids how much fun running can be and the healthy benefits of running. The camp will last two hours with approximately one hour spent learning about running and the body, and the other hour doing some sort of physical activity that involves running. Each day we will have an activity which will not just be a run. Some days we will be running as a group, participating in relays, and a variety of other games will be played. If you are looking for a camp in which your child can be active, this is the camp for you. On the last day of the camp (Friday) we will host a mini track meet in which parents can watch kids participate in a variety of running events. There will be awards for the finishers in each race. The more participants in this camp the better due to the track meet finale! Information will also be passed out concerning the Big Sky State games if your child wants to participate in a larger event. We will also explore, different types of races, famous runners, necessary items for runners, important muscles and much more!|438|06/02/2009|438|06/03/2009

55459|event_desc|This is a camp that is designed to teach kids how to tell a story. Throughout the camp, they will be read numerous childrens stories and then have time to develop their own characters and story plot. They will make the plot into a story. They will illustrate their book, design a cover, and even make an about the author page. They will have the opportunity to either take the paper book home bounded as they would like, or, for a small charge (usually under ten dollars) send it off to be published as a regular book (bound and printed by an actual publishing company). The book will arrive in the mail the week after the camp is over. Students will work on the book at camp and may take the book home to continue working on it. At the end of the week, they will have a book that they wrote. We will also spend the day reading childrens books and getting ideas. We will also explore, different types of books, characters, story plot and the terms associated with it, literary elements and how to get published!  |438|06/02/2009|438|10/27/2009

55594|event_desc|pARTiciate is a workshop series for educators that offers credit for attending a variety of arts events around Billings including music, dance and theater at the Alberta Bair Theater, museum tours at the Yellowstone Art Museum, dress rehearsals of the Billings Symphony and Rimrock Opera, local theater productions of Venture Theatre and the annual YMCA Writers Voice Bookfest. Educators are encouraged to experience as many events as their schedule can handle to broaden and deepen their understanding of the arts. The series includes a reflection workshop that offers information and hands-on activities that demonstrate how all the arts are connected. Attendance at the reflection workshop is mandatory.  Teachers of all grades are encouraged to register.   Each event is worth two or three hours of credit time. The reflection workshop and the Symphony and Opera rehearsals are each worth three hours. All other events are worth two hours. Select a total of 15 hours of arts events including the reflection workshop to receive one semester credit.  Please note: You must first register with the Alberta Bair Theater by calling 256  8915 or email fredlund@albertabairtheater.org  Basic registration fee for 15 hours is $100, payable to the ABT.   The series is presented by the Alberta Bair Theater, in cooperation with the Billings Symphony, Rimrock Opera, Venture Theatre, Yellowstone Art Museum and YMCAs Writers Voice.|335|09/01/2009|438|08/23/2010

55600|event_desc|Join us for an hour of arts and culture at the Yellowstone Art Museum. Members will be given a guided tour of the museum and various art collections. The tour guide will include educational references to historical works of art, as well as draw parallels between other modern and contemporary artists. Members will be able to view the PostSecret collection by Frank Warren that includes the results of his blanket invitation to anyone to send him an anonymous postcard revealing a secret that was true and had never been uttered before. "Five years and thousands of postcards later, this incredible and profound outpouring has been the raw material for several books and this traveling exhibition. You'll never think about a secret or the postal service the same way again!" Members will also view the museum's permanent art collections. Must be a Seniors on Campus member to attend. Please bring $3 admission fee for the tour. Please RSVP by Friday, October 2nd.|3836|09/02/2009|438|11/12/2009
55606|event_desc|Join us for the walking tour of historic downtown Billings and experience the sights and sounds of present day Billings while Keven Kooistra-Manning, WHC Community Historian, shares insights and illustrates with historic photos from the museum collection the changing face of historic downtown Billings. Explore the founding of Billings as a railroad town in 1882, examine architecture old and new, discuss why the city is configured the way it is, and interpret visible ghost signs. This tour promises to offer plenty of surprises about Billings to both long-time Billings residents and visitors alike! 55613|event_desc|Teachers in Montana and Wyoming will take part in the Montana State Reading Conference in Billings, Montana on October 15 and October 16, 2009. Teachers will begin their training at 7:45 each day and end their day at 4:30. Teachers will attend three general sessions wherein keynote speakers are national presenters and authors. Following the general sessions, attendees will choose from approximately 25 breakout sessions or institutes during each day of the two-day conference. Additional opportunities to accumulate hours will be provided by attendance at the 4:45-5:45 Round Table Discussion, the 7-9pm Author Gala, and/or the two author luncheons.   Presenters include master educators from Montana and other states as well as professionals from the Office of Public Education, premier publishers, and nationally known authors and speakers. In addition to Pre-K, Primary, Intermediate/Middle School, Secondary, and Adult level strands, this conference offers sessions in Reading Strategies, Technology, Educational Research, Writing, and Diversity. Featured keynote speakers include: Mary Bigler and Scott Miller as well as authors Bill Pack (adult fiction), Chris Crutcher (Intermediate-Secondary), and Patricia Reilly Giff (Primary-Intermediate). 55616|event_desc|The concept of Gracious Space was developed through the Center for Ethical Leadership (www.ethicalleadership.org) and is being used by organizations and groups all over the country.  The concept is to create a safe atmosphere that contributes to relationship building.  By creating a shared vision for your group it is more likely to be productive and foster healthy and strong relationships.  Members learn to work together cooperatively despite differences in their age, gender, race or ethnicity.  All ideas are valued.  Gracious Space is not conversation or debate in the absence of conflict or tension; participants learn ways to work through difficult and challenging conversations through mutual respect.  The concept has been used successfully in many arenas including health care, government, community, non-profit groups and schools.  Practitioners of this philosophy find they are less judgmental, better listeners and more able to be open.  The result is an increase in productivity, creativity, and the opportunity for new understandings of others.  |438|09/14/2009|438|11/02/2009
55617|event_desc|NASA education specialist for Montana will facilitate a 15 hour inquiry-based education course over 4 days at MSU for teachers of grades 4-10. The course includes an overview of NASA Education materials and resources. Educators will be introduced and participate in numerous NASA STEM related activities in the areas of life sciences  and physical sciences (earth, space, etc) which will be applicable to their district curriculums. Participants will be expected to outline classroom implementation for several of the activities introduced. Follow up to area schools can be requested to help teachers with classroom implementation.  |438|09/14/2009|438|01/20/2010

55639|event_desc|To provide an introduction to the American economic system and the American culture to students from other countries.   In addition to the course objective stated above, this course contributes to the learning of certain skills determined by the faculty in the College of Business at Montana State University-Billings in accordance with AACSB guidelines.    The colleges mission statement says that the academic programs of the college develop student competencies in: (1) oral and written communication, (2) critical and creative thinking, (3) quantitative skills, (4) effective utilization of information and technology for business decisions, (5) ethical decision making, and (6) the effect of globalization in business.   In this course, the following learning goals are addressed:   Oral communications:  There will be substantial opportunity for verbal interaction with various faculty, community members and area business leaders.  Students also will make a presentation on the economy of Dubai.   Written communications: A final paper will provide an opportunity to practice and work towards continued improvement in writing skills.    Critical and creative thinking:  The presentation and final paper will provide opportunities to demonstrate critical and creative thinking skills.   Quantitative skills:  Although economic statistics will be discussed, quantitative skills will not be significantly addressed in this course.    Effective utilization of information and technology for business decisions:  This area will not be significantly addressed in this course    Ethics:  Although ethics topics may be discussed, this area will not be significantly addressed in this course   Globalization of business:  The entire course will address economic and business issues and activities in the United States as compared and contrasted with those in Dubai.  In addition, the final paper requires students to address this area.|438|09/18/2009|438|09/15/2010

55776|event_desc|This course will teach the beginning concepts of digital photography starting with the different types of cameras. Students will be instructed on what kinds of cameras and photography equipment is available for various types of photography. The needs of the students will be different and so will the tools or the cameras. The course will continue into the concepts of exposure and how the operator must control the settings on the camera to obtain an optimum file or a photograph sufficient for printing. Moving on, the instructor will explain through examples, the concepts of composition, what makes a good photograph and the art of seeing through focal lengths. Photographs are captured moments in time. Moments are fleeting and are better to be anticipated for the photographer to capture them. As the course moves forward the students will learn how to anticipate a moment and then capture that moment to be recorded as a file or photograph. The instructor will take the students away from class into the field to ZooMontana helping them make their own photographs. They will be instructed and evaluated on exposure and composition in the field. The students will be brought back into the classroom and their photographs will be put into the computer and viewed and critiqued. The very basic concepts of Photoshop or photo-computer manipulation will be demonstrated. This is a very important step in finishing up a digital photograph that will later be viewed on a computer or displayed in print. This two-day intensive learning experience will give you ideas on how to make better pictures to use for publication. Bring your cameras and ideas and learn to create photographs like you have always wanted.   |438|11/10/2009|438|09/16/2010

55855|event_desc|Differentiated Instruction is the concept of making learning opportunities equally accessible for all students.  This  brain-based instruction is something that the brain wants to learn and then seeks its own rewards.  Problem-based learning encourages students to define the problem and seek solutions.  At its most basic level, differentiating instruction changes what goes on in the classroom so that students have many options for acquiring information, making sense of ideas and expressing what they learn.(Tomlinson, 1995)  This course is designed to provide an overview of differentiated instruction as well as providing participants with tools to assess, design and  evaluate instruction techniques for reaching all students.|438|01/07/2010|438|04/21/2010

55862|event_desc|On this extraordinary trip you will canoe with Dr. Keith Edgerton (Ph.D. in American Studies and 20-plus years of university-level teaching experience) and experienced guides the entire length of the Upper Missouri River Breaks National Monument, (149 river miles), for approximately 9.5 days of river travel.  This is one of the most unique wilderness experiences in the United States as a substantial portion of the Monument has been designated as Wild and Scenic, it is roadless, rugged, and remote.  If you would like to   get away from it all immerse yourself in the history, geology, and natural environment of one of the most beautiful places in the U.S.   experience the extended solitude on a stretch of river virtually unchanged since Lewis and Clark traveled through it over 200 years ago   or challenge yourself personally this is a once-in-a-lifetime experience.  We will canoe approximately 15 miles per day with the current (there are no whitewater or rapids on the upper Missouri).  The canoeing is safe and relatively easy.  You will be issued a life jacket and are encouraged to wear it while in the water.  There will be numerous stops for:  hiking   group discussion   wildlife and geological viewing   periodic wilderness-based recreation   as we travel through some of the most historic, scenic, isolated, and unspoiled wilderness in the American West.  We will camp out the entire time, 2 persons per tent.  As part of the group you will be expected to help with camp set up and break down, and assist with basic camp chores as part of the experience   There will be plenty of time for personal journaling (part of the course requirement if you use the experience for college credit), reading, reflection, solitude, in addition to daily socializing and recreational activities.    Topics we will focus on will include:   Montana and American Historyfocusing on Lewis and Clark, the fur trading era, Native/white relations, the steamboat and gold rush eras, and the homesteading era (approximately 10,000 BC to the present)   Environmental Historyfocusing on changing land and resource use by humans (10,000 BC to the present), land management policies, environmental ethics, the impact of and tensions between recreation and ranching, politics of the BLM and other government agencies management decisions.   Native American historyfocusing on historic cultural and living patterns, land use, fur trading, inter-tribal warfare, disease, and the transition to the reservation era of today   Geology and Physical Geographyfocusing on the particularly rich 100 million year geologic record revealed in the Upper Missouri River Breaks National Monument   Additional sub-issues such as stream hydrology, wilderness health and first aid, geo-navigating, canoeing, hiking, and other outdoor skills and activities will also be part of the experience.|438|01/12/2010|438|06/25/2010
55864|event_desc|The concept of Gracious Space was developed through the Center for Ethical Leadership (www.ethicalleadership.org) and is being used by organizations and groups all over the country.  The concept is to create a safe atmosphere that contributes to relationship building.  By creating a shared vision for your group it is more likely to be productive and foster healthy and strong relationships.  Members learn to work together cooperatively despite differences in their age, gender, race or ethnicity.  All ideas are valued.  Gracious Space is not conversation or debate in the absence of conflict or tension; participants learn ways to work through difficult and challenging conversations through mutual respect.  The concept has been used successfully in many arenas including health care, government, community, non-profit groups and schools.  Practitioners of this philosophy find they are less judgmental, better listeners and more able to be open.  The result is an increase in productivity, creativity, and the opportunity for new understandings of others.|438|01/12/2010|438|01/12/2010

55870|event_desc|Writer Fred DeFauw cannot exaggerate the abject consequences that World War I produced. 37,000,000 casualtiesthrough death, wounds and irreparable psychological and emotional damage. The above figure does not include the mental and emotional toll on family members. In Europe alone, a whole generation of young men was lost. The social and economic infrastructure of Europe collapsed. The political and social unrest in much of Europe and Africa that occurred during the remainder of the Twentieth Century was shaped by World War I. This catastrophic event shattered the old rules and conventional views of art. The art, music and literature that evolved has shaped our present Western culture. This class will feature the literature that reflected and was the consequence of World War I.|438|01/12/2010|438|02/19/2010

55921|event_desc|The objective of this course is to introduce drawing and to challenge the student to learn various techniques beyond a pencil point on paper.  The student will see that skillful drawing can be an art in itself or a basic necessity for skillful painting.  Drawing will be presented as a pleasurable, creative endeavor that can be practiced anywhere by anyone.  The objectives will be achieved through study of value range primarily with vine charcoal, using a bold, gestural approach.  The emphasis will be on seeing the mass of the subject before the detail.  Developing ways of fine-tuning the ability to SEE the subject will be introduced, including blind contour drawing and focus on negative space.  Basic laws of perspective will be covered.  The human face will be the primary focus but other objects such as bones, bricks, and unusual shaped objects will be used.  A list of books on art and drawing will be included, as well as introduction to masters of drawing to further explore the pleasure of drawing.|438|02/08/2010|438|02/08/2010

55936|event_desc|The need for more intellectual communication on trade and energy issues between Canada and the United States is apparent. The Canadians watch the American elephant very closely, but Americans are amazingly ignorant of what happens north of the 49th parallel. Energy issues are very high on the agenda of both countries, and they are intimately linked. Canada has the second largest oil reserves in the world, and is the #1 source of U.S. oil importsmost of which come by pipeline through Montana. Canada provides 85% of U.S. imports of natural gas. The continued growth of the Alberta and Saskatchewan oil sands will create high paid jobs in pipelines, refineries and support industries. Montanas Colleges of Technology want to be major providers of job training.   |438|02/16/2010|438|03/16/2010
55940|event_desc|Pysanky is the ancient art of Ukrainian Egg Design.  In this class you will learn the traditional Russian method of intricately decorating eggs with wax and dye.  These eggs which are created during lent and given at Easter are an extraordinary expression of good wishes to the recipient.  You will have fun and learn a beautiful ancient art form.  You will have time to create several eggs in class.  In addition you will learn the history of this fascinating tradition.  Instructor Barb Petak is known for her exquisite Ukrainian egg designs.  The Ukrainian Ambassador has one of Barbaras eggs in his private collection.  Barb only teaches this class during lent to follow the ancient tradition.  Space is limited. The steadier your hand, the more intricate the designs you can create.   |438|02/17/2010|438|02/19/2010

55976|event_desc|This two-day workshop focuses on enhancing vocabulary knowledge for all adolescents in  grades 5-12 and on improving content understanding through comprehension strategies that work  for both narrative and informational text. These two sessions are appropriate for intervention,  English-language learner Staff and all content teachers.  Vocabulary Development  Participants learn and practice research-proven methods to directly  teach important content vocabulary, teach students to figure out unknown words using contextual  analysis and morphemic analysis skills, and engage in fun and stimulating activities that foster  word consciousness. Participants will receive more than 30 sample lesson models with easy  application to classroom text in any academic content area.  Comprehension Strategies and Text Structures  Participants learn about current, validated  research in comprehension instruction and receive an overview of the factors known to positively  impact comprehension. Participants receive in-depth instruction in selected instructional  techniques that have broad application in both narrative and informational text at all grade levels,  including content classes. These techniques encompass the following:   Teacher interaction with students with an emphasis on question techniques   Instruction in recognizing information text structures   Specific strategies for helping students understand internet sources.   Identifying the main idea, summarizing and making inferences.|438|03/23/2010|438|08/20/2010

Teams of teachers from the same school are encouraged to attend the institute together.  Through a series of interactive, hands-on workshops that are standards-driven, and include a foundation for behavior management, authentic assessment, and time for lesson planning, this institute demonstrates how using the arts to teach across the curriculum makes effective use of instructional time. Teachers will have the opportunity to reflect on their skills, adapt strategies to fit their needs, and exchange ideas with colleagues. The first 3 days of this institute will focus on participating in, and learning, the instructional strategies. 56012|event_desc|The concept of Gracious Space was developed through the Center for Ethical Leadership (www.ethicalleadership.org) and is being used by organizations and groups all over the country.  The concept is to create a safe atmosphere that contributes to relationship building.  By creating a shared vision for your group it is more likely to be productive and foster healthy and strong relationships.  Members learn to work together cooperatively despite differences in their age, gender, race or ethnicity.  All ideas are valued. Project Based Learning (PBL) is a systematic teaching method that engages students in learning knowledge and skills through an extended inquiry process structured around complex, authentic questions and carefully designed products and tasks. 51370|req_mtrls|Participants should be able to use Microsoft Word to create, edit, format, save, and print business documents that contain text, tables, and graphics. Participants should also be able to use a Web browser and an email program. A basic understanding of XML would also be helpful. In order to understand how Word interacts with other applications in the Microsoft Office System, participants should have a basic understanding of how worksheets and presentations work. To ensure success, we recommend participants first take our Microsoft Word Level 1 and 2 training courses or have equivalent knowledge base.|438|10/28/2007|469|04/03/2006

55570|req_mtrls|Oil paint (one 37-ml tube of these colors: cadmium yellow light, cadmium orange, cadmium red medium, ultramarine blue, viridian, sap green, dioxazine violet (at the very minimum, a red, a yellow, a blue) Average price: $10/tube     Brushes: Bristle brushes, 3 minimum (preferably size 4 and larger) variety of rounds, flats, and brights Average price: $20-30 total     Palette knives: one small (approx. 1 inch blade) with pointed tip, one larger (approx. 2 inch blade or larger Average price: $10     Paint scraper: for cleaning your palette (if using glass or plexiglass) Average $3.00     Palette: at least 12x16, preferably of glass or plexiglass, but disposable paper palettes are suitable Can be ordered from glass shop Average $5.00     2 containers for brush cleaner: a small metal nut can works well     Paper towels: one roll     Canvas boards: four, various sizes from 8x10 to 12x16 Average $15.00 total     Gloves: recommended to protect hands from paint and solvent    Easel, portable: if you have one. I prefer that students stand while painting, but if not possible, students can paint using a table easel and chair. A portable French easel works well and can be used either for standing or sitting positions.    If a student has no painting supplies of his own, the estimate for a basic set up is $75-$100.  |3836|08/21/2009|438|11/12/2009

49264|caf_cmts|1st Credit:  Students will be required to attend all 15 hours of class.  Some of the structured time would be allowed for individual research.  The students will be required to present their findings to the class.  The students will be required to create a group project.  They will also be required to provide testimony in a mock legislative hearing with judges asking questions and giving feedback.    2nd Credit:  Students will be required to journal and document that they have spent 45 hours of participation in their classroom with their students working on Project Citizen.  The teacher will need to create a timeline for activities or a lesson outline for the project, which should cover at least 4 weeks.  His/Her class must complete the project and enter it in the state competition.  The project must meet national guidelines.||10/28/2007||

49321|caf_cmts|Participants are expected to bring items of oral folklore, (songs, stories, poems, jokes, etc.), customary folklore (gestures, games, ceremonies/rituals, etc.), or material folklore (toys, folk foods, tools, etc.) for sharing, discussion and analysis.  They will write either (1) A brief paper (3-8 pages) analyzing one or more of the items discussed or brought to class or (2) a lesson plan for using folklore in the classroom, geared to the appropriate grade.||10/28/2007||
49322|caf_cmts|Participants are expected to bring items of oral folklore, (songs, stories, poems, jokes, etc.), customary folklore (gestures, games, ceremonies/rituals, etc.), or material folklore (toys, folk foods, tools, etc.) for sharing, discussion and analysis.  They will write either (1) A brief paper (3-8 pages) analyzing one or more of the items discussed or brought to class or (2) a lesson plan for using folklore in the classroom, geared to the appropriate grade.||10/28/2007||
